DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report:
(a) the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia today, including:
(i) lawyers' fees, charges and overheads,
(ii) courts-delays, costs, listing arrangements, hours of operation and overheads, and
(iii) Government charges;
(b) whether the cost of taking legal action is unacceptably high;
(c) the availability and targeting of legal aid; and
(d) whether there are any practicable alternatives to the present system.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement, relating to the reference, which has been brilliantly prepared by my staff.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The cost of legal services is already an issue, and it is becoming a bigger one. There is presently legislation before the Victorian Parliament providing that where the matter in dispute involves $5000 or less, the litigants are not entitled to costs. In recent times there have been moves towards conciliators and arbitrators rather than courts to resolve disputes. These processes are seen as cheaper than the traditional ones. Besides concern about the cost of litigation there has been much debate about the cost of non-litigious legal services such as conveyancing. Lawyers say that their overheads are high.

There has been much criticism of lawyers because of the expense of legal services. It would be counter-productive of this Committee to join in a witchhunt. The Committee believes that most lawyers, like other professional groups, are genuinely hard working persons. For this reason, the Committee will be looking at lawyers' fees and charges not in isolation but in the context of the overheads involved in running their practices. In examining the overall cost of legal services, the Committee wants to consider aspects of lawyers' professional practice to gauge whether they have an effect on the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia today. Some such aspects include, for example, the two counsel rule or the split nature of the profession in some States.

Beyond the costs associated directly with lawyers, other factors may contribute to the cost of obtaining justice in Australia. Such factors include the listing arrangements in courts, the monetary jurisdictional limits of the courts, the awarding of costs, and legal representation in small claims jurisdictions or before certain tribunals, for example.

The Committee will be asking whether there are ways of streamlining court procedures so as to reduce the costs of those procedures. It will examine, for example, whether measures such as longer sitting hours, grouped proceedings, contingency fees, or increased incentives for people to try alternative, informal, means of resolving disputes may be practical.

The Committee also wants to look at the factors that affect the cost of non-litigious legal work-for example, should conveyancing, or the incorporation of companies, be the exclusive province of lawyers?

One of the concerns the Committee has in undertaking an inquiry such as this is that the community's reasonable expectations of obtaining justice should not be unduly compromised. As far as the Committee is concerned, there is a balance to be achieved between an acceptable level of justice and an acceptable cost to individuals and to the community.

Another concern of the Committee in this inquiry will be the availability and targeting of legal aid. Again there is a balance to be achieved between the provision of reasonable services to the community and reasonable costs being borne by the Australian taxpayer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (DISQUALIFICATION OF MEMBERS AND CANDIDATES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution with respect to the qualification and disqualification of Members of the Parliament and Parliamentary Candidates.
Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to remove discrimination against public servants standing for election to federal Parliament.
Under section 44 (iv) of the Constitution, any person who holds any office of profit under the Crown is incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or member of the House of Representatives.

This is interpreted as meaning that public servants must resign or take unpaid leave of absence from their jobs before they can nominate as a candidate for election to either House of federal Parliament.
The question of the validity of this interpretation of the Constitution has, of course, been raised many times in the past.

Bills have been introduced on this topic, but came to nothing. In February 1980, Australian Democrats' Senator Mason raised the question, requesting that the then Government re-examine Public Service General Order 3/D/4 which stated that a member of the public service must resign before nomination for election to a House of federal Parliament. As a result of this motion, the question was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, who reported in 1981 that Commonwealth and State public servants do not have equal rights with other citizens to seek election to the Commonwealth Parliament. The Committee concluded that two important principles should be upheld:
``(a) to ensure that a member or senator is not simultaneously a member of the Commonwealth Parliament and a Commonwealth public servant and in receipt of two salaries as a result; and
(b) to ensure that Commonwealth public servants are not effectively discouraged from standing for the Commonwealth Parliament.''

The Committee recommended that ``a simple but effective solution lies in taking as the crucial date the date at which a person elected to Parliament becomes entitled to a parliamentary allowance and providing for the resignation of a public service candidate, who is elected, to be effective from that date. If the Constitution is amended to provide that a person who holds what is presently termed an `office of profit' is to be deemed to have vacated that office at the date that he or she becomes entitled to payment of a parliamentary allowance, these two principles will be satisfied.''

In 1985, former Senator Colin Mason had this Bill drafted to put that recommendation into effect. The Bill lapsed with his retirement from Parliament, and in the interests of public servants I now restore it to the notice paper, in the hope that it will finally be acted upon.

The view that public servants must resign before nomination has, of course, been modified, so they are now required only to take leave without pay. The prospect of at least four weeks with no income whatsoever is, however, a daunting one for the most hardy among us, and for someone with the responsibility of paying rent or a mortgage, and buying food, it provides a hefty barrier to nomination for election to federal Parliament.

Honourable senators will remember the case of Mr Bill Woods, who was refused re-employment after contesting the Queensland seat of Leichhardt in 1977, on the specific instructions of the then Queensland Premier. Under the present ruling this situation could not occur. However, this can change at any time, and under the existing, often-disputed wording of this section of the Constitution, resignation from the public service could again become a necessary precursor to nomination for election to the federal Parliament. Resignation may carry with it, of course, adverse effects on superannuation benefits and credit loan interest rates, and may even affect housing and, as in Mr Woods' case, jeopardise future employment.
It is not good enough that the rights of all Australians in the public service are limited so unjustly.
The right to stand for Parliament is a most important and cherished right. We must protect it by all possible means.
One of the most important is to be found in this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
In moving that the Bill be read a second time I ask the Parliament to endorse four historic commitments. This Bill would establish:
a secure fair deal for families with children;
a guarantee of adequate standards of income for children;
for the first time maintenance of the real value of family payments;
indexation of pensions and benefits at the earliest possible date.

In 1966, the Arbitration Commission did away with the basic wage. From that time on Australia has not had a wages system that takes account of the costs of children. From that time fair income distribution has been a function exclusively for the tax and social security systems. Since then the social security system has been required to make sure working families have adequate income to care for all children.

Australia owes much to Professor Ronald Henderson for his clear articulation, as early as 1970, that the 1966 moves in the wages system would compel attention in public policy. He spelt out that we would have to address through tax and social security policy the issues of equity between families with and without children and the adequacy of incomes for all families with children.

The report of the commission of inquiry into poverty highlighted what issues had to be addressed. The work of that commission led to the Whitlam government converting deductions for children into tax rebates and to the Fraser government's cashing out the rebates to family allowance.

With the benefit of hindsight we can see that those moves were not sustained. The issues of fairness of the tax treatment of families and adequacy of family income, having been addressed by Henderson were not further addressed for some years.
Not until the social security review were the issues thought through. The issues addressed by the review include:
first the balance between horizontal equity measures-like family allowance-and vertical equity measures-like family allowance supplement and additional pension/benefit;

second the make-up of families and the importance of adequate provision for all family types-couples with one and two incomes, sole parents, families with pre-school age children, school children and teenagers, families with children with disabilities;
third, to which family member should particular payments go; and
fourth, standards of adequacy for families with inadequate incomes.

Professor Cass's issues Paper No. 1 of the Social Security Review, Income Support for Families with Children is the first comprehensive analysis of the detailed policies required to build a fair, secure policy that deals with the issues identified by Henderson 20 years ago.

Cass identified short-term measures which were demanded by the appalling extent of poverty among families with children. Over the last two years those recommendations have been progressively implemented through the families package: family allowance supplement was introduced, payable to the mother; child disability allowance was introduced, differential rates of payment for younger and older children have been introduced; massive increases in payments per child have occurred; family allowance supplement and family allowance have been integrated into a single payment.
With this Bill we move the short term to the long term recommendations of Professor Cass-addressing the more fundamental issue of horizontal equity and sustaining the system into the future.
This Bill proposes the biggest increases in family allowance in history.

In 1976 when tax rebates for children were cashed out by the Fraser Government assistance for working families was cut-from $4.50 per week for the first child to $3.50. This was done by converting the tax rebate for the first child of $200 a year into an increase of $3 a week in family allowance to a total of $3.50.

In 1982, the Fraser Government gave its first and only family allowance increase-of $1.75 a week to $5.25, a net increase in assistance for the first child of 75 cents a week in 7 years. With this Bill I ask for Parliament's endorsement of a rise of $3.75 a week to $9-an increase of 71% for the first child in every family.

The Bill would massively simplify the family allowance system. The current system of four rates of allowance will be replaced with two rates: $9 a week for the first, second and third child and $12 a week for fourth and subsequent children and for children in institutions. This new simple structure accords with proposals of the Social Security Review-a basic family allowance at a flat rate, with special recognition for larger families.
The increase to family allowance would directly benefit almost 2 million families with 3.8 million children.
The family allowance system to be implemented by this Bill is simple, fair and sustainable.
The Bill would index all family allowance payments in line with movements in the CPI. This fair deal for families will not be eroded by inflation.

The fair deal for Australian families in this Bill is complemented by the major rises in, and annual indexation of, the dependent spouse rebate and sole parent rebate announced by the Treasurer in the April Tax Statement.
In our policy commitments at the last election we promised that `during Labor's third term adequate living standards for children will be achieved by:
raising child payments to ensure that total assistance per child moves from its current level of 11 per cent to at least 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension; and
Ensuring that the aggregate payments for older children attain a benchmark of 20 per cent of the combined married rate.''
With this Bill this Labor Government delivers on that promise.

That promise was made because of our firm belief that the greatest scourge facing our nation is child poverty, that we must put an end to that, and that there is only one way to do that: to guarantee adequate income for all children.
This Bill delivers on our promise-putting behind us the scandal of child poverty.

The levels of child payments set by this Bill are consistent with Australian research on the income needs of families with children. For the first time in Australian history a government has set a standard for child payments that is adequate and will be maintained in real terms.

Professor Henderson in the Commission of inquiry into poverty recommended payments equivalent to 12%, 15% and 18% of the payments for a married couple respectively for first, second and third children. The package we have announced tonight of 15% of married rate pension for each younger child and 20% for 13 to 15 year olds goes beyond the Poverty Commission's work-providing for the first time in history a guaranteed income for families at a higher real level than recommended by the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty.

On the basis of the social security review's work Labor made its commitment to benchmarks for child payments-a commitment to establish enduring relativities between families with children and people without children.
For the first time in Australia we have a policy based on what it costs to raise children-rather than on what happens to be available in the Budget process.

That policy that recognises the costs of children has built in what every parent of teenagers knows, and all the research shows: teenagers cost more. In just 18 months we have introduced and won universal acceptance for a higher rate for teenage children.

These policies are complemented by the common allowance structure for youth incomes. We have put in place income support of 15% of married rate pension for children up to 12, 20% for 13 to 15 year olds and 25% for 16 and 17 year olds.
This Bill would implement the guaranteed standards of adequacy from 1 July this year.

Building on Henderson's work the social security review examined in detail 30 separate studies of equivalence scales-of the relativities of income needs or expenditure patterns between different family types and sizes.

For younger children family allowance of $9 a week plus family allowance supplement of $24 a week will be payable-a total of $33 a week per child. For 13 to 15 year olds the increases in family allowance will be added to by a $3.10 increase in family allowance supplement providing a combined payment of $43.10 per week per child-in comparison to the $15.25 available when we came to government.

Reaching those standards means massive real increases in payments for 1.1 million children in low income families. The level of those payments line up with Australian research on income needs of families. The days of policy based on anecdote, of increases based on what is left over at the end of the budget process are behind us. Policy is now based on explicit standards that are available for rigorous scrutiny.
The third commitment I ask of the Parliament is indexation of family payments and maintenance of the standards of adequacy.
As a nation we like to think of ourselves as placing our children first.
Until this Bill the actions of this Parliament have not placed our children first. We have fully indexed payments for adults-offering them some security and protection from the ravages of inflation.
Before this Bill no Government had ever committed itself to maintenance of payments to families with children in real terms. This Labor Government has now done so.
The Bill seeks to index family payments: family allowance, mothers/guardians allowance, child disability allowance, multiple birth payment and double orphans pensions.
The first indexation increase will be on the first payday in 1990. Family allowance will be adjusted in line with the increase in the CPI between December 1988 and the June quarter this year.
After that family allowance will be indexed annually with effect from the first payday each calendar year in line with movements in the CPI in the preceding financial year.

Mothers/guardians allowance, child disability allowance, multiple birth payment and double orphans pension will each be indexed on the first payday in 1990 and each year after that. Increases will be in line with CPI movements in the preceding financial year.

I have already referred to the real declines in tax and family allowance provisions for families with children under the previous government. All families suffered in that period because payments and rebates were not adjusted for inflation.

For low income families the absence of that adjustment was devastating-800,000 children were forced into poverty. Payments for children in low income families were increased in nominal terms only once in 7 years from $7.50 to $10.00-a real decline of 35%. Under Labor those payments have been increased every year-in 1983 from $10 to $12; in 1984 from $12 to $14; in 1985 from $14 to $16; in 1986 from $16 to $17; in 1987 from $17 to $22 for younger children and $28 for older children; in 1988 from $22 to $24 for younger children and $28 to $31 for older children.
This Bill proposes a further increase for older children in 1989 from $31 to $34.10 and historic rises in family allowance for all children.
The Bill would guarantee these gains would not be eroded by inflation.
On top of family allowance indexation, family allowance supplement, additional pension and additional benefit will be adjusted from the first payday each calendar year.

This adjustment will increase rates of FAS and additional pension/benefit whenever necessary to maintain the standards of adequacy. Total payments for children in low income families would be guaranteed as a percentage of married rate pension-which is automatically indexed in line with the CPI.
The standards of living of low income families with children will never again be subject to decimation through policy indolence and lethargy of governments.
All members of this Parliament are asked to step beyond attitudes and to commit themselves to a solid policy-of a secure and fair deal for families.

For the last year we have had vigorous debate in Australia on the appropriate levels and type of provision for families with children. That debate is central to any concern about fairness and equity in our community.
To quote Professor Cass:

in a period of restraint on public expenditure it is essential to address the matter of immediate priorities for family assistance. This focusses attention on those approaches which provide greater assistance to low income families by improving adequacy of income-tested payments for pensioners, beneficiaries and low income working families and introducing measures which minimise work disincentives and support the transition to employment.
There she described in 1986 the processes the Government has implemented in the last two years. She went on:

proposals for reform based on the principle of horizontal equity have the long-term objective of improving and maintaining the disposable incomes of families with children relative to individuals and couples without children . . .

The value at which family allowances might be set is obviously contentious, with the terms of debate set within the outer limits of appropriate assistance with the costs of children on the one hand, and the capacity of government revenue and the willingness of the political process to redistribute to families, on the other hand.

This Bill together with the Treasurer's announced increases and indexation of family taxation rebates delivers a fair, sustainable deal for all families with a guarantee of adequate income for all families with children. There is a balance involved-a balance that until this Bill Australian public policy has addressed for 20 years in an ad hoc way.

The balance we have struck provides a fair distribution of income; and provides a guarantee of income for every family which is adequate for them to share fully in the life of our community. It accords with the very essence of social justice.

Sustainable, equitable social reform is never easy, never quick. This package is a fair sustainable deal for families. Professor Henderson indicated the need for it 20 years ago. Professor Cass did the detailed work on how to do it and spelt out the process to achieve it. With this Bill, we propose to deliver it.
We will deliver for all children-whether they live in one or two parent families, whether one, two or no parents work, or whether they live in institutions.

Just as in family policy we have known of the issues for many years; just as we needed the social security review to look at the detail and work through the detailed processes, so we are entering upon a detailed review of retirement income.
In October 1988 the social security review released issues paper Number 6, Towards a National Retirement Incomes Policy.

Following release of that paper, the Government initiated an extensive series of community consultations on retirement income policies. The Prime Minister's task force on retirement income has travelled to all States to meet with, and listen to, several thousand pensioners and retired people at some forty separate meetings.

The Australian Council of Social Service, in conjunction with the Australian Pensioners Federation, has also undertaken an extensive consultation process to obtain the views of pensioners and the community welfare sector.

The Government has been consulting State governments, trade unions, business, the superannuation industry and relevant national organisations, as well as considering the many written submissions received in response to the social security review issues paper.

In the April Tax Statement we announced two measures that were both recommended by the Social Security Review, the Prime Minister's Task Force on Retirement Income, consultations and submissions received by the Government. These initiatives form part of a phased reform of retirement income to improve adequacy, fairness, security and sustainability.

In addition to recommendations from the Social Security Review and from the subsequent consultations, the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs recommended that the Government should reduce the lag between the release of the CPI figures and the indexation of pension payments.
The Government has therefore decided to bring forward pension indexation increases in three stages. Each stage will bring the indexation increase forward by four weeks.
The Bill would provide for indexation dates to be 15 November 1989, 18 April 1990, and then each September and March.
Indexation dates would be brought forward in total by 12 weeks.

Consultations on retirement income have also shown quite clearly that the differing free areas for tax and social security confuse many age pensioners. The Government has therefore decided to ensure that the income test free area will become 100 per cent tax free. This will be achieved by setting the pensioner tax rebate at an appropriate level.

The Treasurer's announcement that the pension free area is to become tax free is a major reform. No previous Government has ever committed itself to a standard for the amount of non-pension income that pensioners can receive without paying tax.

This announcement together with the changes to indexation dates are a clear statement of the Government's direction in retirement income policy. They will enable people contemplating retirement to plan for their future with the security that their real levels of total income will be protected.

In 1989-90 a single pensioner will be able to receive $25 per week on top of the maximum rate of pension without having to pay tax. In 1990-91 this amount will be increased to $40 so that the income test free area is totally tax free.

In 1989-90 married couples will be able to receive $35 per week each tax free. This means that married couples will be able to receive 100% of their pension income test free area without paying any tax.

The Government's decision will also mean an extra 75,000 pensioners will not pay provisional tax. This is because all pensioners receiving the pensioner tax rebate are exempted from paying provisional tax.

This Government has repaired the damage done by the previous government-by repairing the income security safety net, by protecting the safety net from inflation through indexation and automatic adjustment and by restoring employment.

Last month unemployment benefit numbers fell to less than 400,000-the lowest figure since 1982. Unfortunately those who have been unemployed longest are finding it hardest to take advantage of employment growth.
Newstart offers a leg up to those people-to end their scarring and exclusion. It is available to long term beneficiaries.
With effect from 1 February this year Newstart has been extended to the spouses of long term beneficiaries.
This Bill would extend employment entry payment to those spouses.
The Bill also seeks to correct an anomaly affecting the payment of child disability allowance.

Under the current legislation, in some cases child disability allowance may not be payable where a father is caring for a disabled child. The Bill would make it clear that the family is entitled to the child disability allowance regardless of which parent actually cares for the child.
Experience with the operation of the savings provision introduced with the maintenance income test in June last year has shown the need for refinements in three areas.
First, the Government has decided to restore and backdate fully indexation increases to people in the saved category who are receiving spousal main- tenance only and have no dependent children.

Second, income payments received in arrears would be excluded from the definition of `total income' so that people who receive late what they are entitled to all along maintain the benefit of the savings provision.

Third, the Bill would close a loophole in the maintenance income test savings provision by ensuring that the previous level of benefit is `saved' only to the extent that the client continues to meet the basic eligibility criteria for the payment. It is being made clear, for example, that if a child ceases to be a dependant for the purpose of the payment of additional benefit, then that component of the entitlement ceases.

Entitlement to a one off double payment of benefit to ex-prisoners will be extended to former long-term beneficiaries who reclaim unemployment benefit on release from prison within three months of last receiving unemployment benefit.

The Bill refines rules governing the portability of Australian pensions overseas. This refinement is necessary for the effective negotiation and operation of our reciprocal social security agreements.
Broadly speaking, the rate of pension currently paid overseas after 12 months' absence is based on the proportion of a person's working life spent resident in Australia.

To date, each agreement has contained this rule within its own text. However, future agreements will apply the rule by reference to our domestic social security legislation. It is necessary therefore, to set down this mechanism in the Act.
The Bill would increase penalties for the unauthorised disclosure of client information.

The penalties currently provided by the Act on summary conviction for unlawful disclosure are up to six months' imprisonment or a $1,000 fine. On indictment, an offender can face a gaol term of up to two years or a fine of up to $5,000.
This Bill would raise the fines for breaches of the secrecy provisions contained in the social security act to $3,000 on summary conviction and $12,000 on indictment.
In the last 3 years we have redesigned and rebuilt the system of income support for families with children.

That has involved major changes in the approaches required of the staff in the 220 regional offices, the area and state offices of the department of social security. I place on record the Government's appreciation for the diligence, competence and commitment of all those people who have been charged with delivering those changes.
Those changes have been designed by a large number of dedicated professionals in each of the divisions of the central office of the Department.

Regardless of our political differences, I am sure all senators have seen the changes in social security in the last 3 years and will join with me in congratulating and thanking the secretary and his staff.

I also wish to place on record the Minister's appreciation for the work of Professor Cass as head of the social security review and the many people who have worked for that review. It is their detailed work which has made the package included in this Bill possible.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering 16 Bills comprising the corporations package. Government, Opposition and Democrat amendments to two of the Bills-the Australian Securities Commission Bill 1988 and the Corporations Bill 1988-have been circulated. I understand that agreement has been reached that these two Bills be considered together, but separately from the other 14. —Is it the wish of the Committee that the Australian Securities Commission Bill and the Corporations Bill be considered together and taken as a whole? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a point prior to the debate on the first amendment. Technically, it is on the first clause of the first Bill. The Opposition is unhappy with the way this matter is being handled. Colleagues of mine who have an interest in corporate law and in securities law are distressed at the fact that they have been given inadequate time to consider the Government amendments, which were circulated only on Monday of this week. My colleagues have had inadequate time also to consider the amendments of the Australian Democrats, which were received only yesterday, and the explanatory memoranda, which are important in assisting with the large volume of amendments. I stress that we are not looking simply at a handful of changes. The changes, of which there are some 30 pages, are very significant, and they have only just been distributed in this chamber. It is therefore the Opposition's view that Committee should not be considering these amendments today but that the Parliament, and the Senate in particular, should be given reasonable time not only to read them but also to analyse them and their consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated to the Minister a few moments ago, there are a number of business and commercial organisations within our community which have contacted my colleagues and expressed their wish to comment upon various amendments. The time being allowed by the Government makes that absolutely impossible. We are looking at a package of Bills that has been some years in the making. The Government made 280 of its own amendments in the House of Representatives, which amendments were not properly debated. Now that the Bills are in this chamber we have been presented with 30 more pages of Government amendments on two days notice following a Government response to the Senate Select Committee which was put out by the Government only last Friday. On the Opposition side of the chamber we are at a loss to understand the rush at this stage after the Government has taken so long to reach this stage.

We believe in orderly processing of legislation and amendments. We believe that our colleagues who have an interest in this area should have reasonable time to analyse the changes that the Government is proposing and the Government's response to the Joint Select Committee. That is simply not being permitted by this time frame. I accept that the Government, Senator Bolkus, Senator Macklin and those who have been intimately involved through the Joint Select Committee procedure have a special knowledge and perhaps for them there is not the same time necessity in order to take in new matters of this nature. But this chamber is not simply made up of those who were involved in that process of the Joint Select Committee. It is not simply made up of those who have been principally involved in the negotiation of what might be described as a settlement: Senator Macklin on the one hand and Senator Bolkus on the other. I do not mean that with any disrespect. That is fine as far as they are concerned. But I stress on behalf of the Opposition that there are other honourable senators with an interest in this area who are not being afforded the opportunity within this time frame to meet their responsibilities properly. We therefore suggested to the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) that this matter be delayed a few more days in order that it might be properly processed by the Opposition. I understand that the Government and the Australian Democrats are not prepared to meet that very reasonable request.

TALK.START.PARA: —We might.
—I am referring to instructions from Senator Bolkus this morning.
—Have you got any Opposition senators ready to go on the Wheat Marketing Bill? Line them up and we will think about it.

—We could have someone ready at short notice. The matter is complex. As I said yesterday, the corporations legislation is the largest package of legislation ever introduced into this Parliament. We are looking at 16 separate Bills, literally thousands of pages of legislation and hundreds of amendments that have been introduced by the Government in the other place and we now have more Government amendments in this place. I accept that we have contributed with a series of amendments that I have prepared to try to pick up matters which the Joint Select Committee recommended but which were not adopted by the Government and we think should be adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: There are important questions of principle, particularly relating to the future role of this Parliament in the process, in particular the role of the Parliament through a committee procedure to oversee the whole of this corporate legislative package. It will be the first time that the Parliament has had that opportunity. As yet there are questions to be settled as to the powers to be afforded to that parliamentary committee. It is our view that the powers should not be as restrictive as those included in the amendments we have seen to date. We have the Clerks assisting us at the moment in redrafting some of those amendments in a way that we believe will be in the better interests of this nation.

It is unsatisfactory to have to do it on the run at this last stage. We are confronted with major restructuring of the whole of the corporations and securities law within this nation. There is no urgency that requires that the matter be dealt with today and that the Parliament not be allowed a few days to analyse properly the amendments that are to be brought down en masse by the Government and by other parties who have an interest in this particular debate. On the first clause I want to express that protest on behalf of the Opposition parties in the strongest possible terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of what you have said it would be appropriate, if you wished to do so, to move to report progress. Is that your purpose? You are not obliged to move that if you do not want to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene in this matter as Manager of Government Business in the Senate. We had debate on the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 scheduled for Monday. The Opposition requested that we put off the debate. We also had it scheduled for Tuesday. We put it off again. Our difficulty in this matter is that some other legislation has also been put off, which means that our more vital legislation that has a high priority cannot generally be considered. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill says that he needs more time. We can get a degree of the committee stage completed here today; when we get to an impasse, to a point at which the Opposition can justifiably claim that the legislation is too complex, we can proceed on to other legislation.

I think we should make a start on this today. If we get to a stage where there is nothing left to do, then we will go on to the wheat marketing legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray). I appreciate the goodwill of his comments. If I might speak with due modesty, the problem is not so much that I am not able to deal with the clauses myself, because I have been involved in the last few days, but that our Party as a whole includes people who are interested in this debate and who have not had the opportunity within the rushed timeframe to consider the proposals. I put to the honourable senator that the Government response was put down last Friday. We said that we could not debate it on Monday because, not surprisingly, our party room needed to assess the Government's response--
—And you were distracted by other matters.

—The party room meeting was not until Tuesday morning. Some Opposition members might have been distracted by other matters; some were concentrating on the corporations package. On Tuesday morning the party meeting settled some of the major questions. We agreed, as far as we were able to agree, to complete the second reading debate of the Copyright Amendment Bill 1989 yesterday. That was duly done. We said to the Government that we felt we would have difficulty yesterday moving to the committee stage of the corporations legislation because of the compressed timeframe and because the detail had not been analysed. We were hoping that all of our people--
—There was a direct promise of cooperation.

—I will always cooperate and I will do my utmost to facilitate the passage of this very complicated set of Bills in a way that is not going to hinder the overall program of the Government. It is one of these packages where obviously debate, even though reasonable analysis of the various provisions of this package, could take a long time. I will not be seeking to do that. We have sought to avoid that by expediting its consideration through a joint select committee. We are narrowing the potential for argument and debate by these various means. In actual fact, there was only half an hour of the second reading debate left yesterday. We now get to the complicated part of the committee stage of this Bill. I again put our position to the Minister, reciprocating the goodwill he is showing in approaching this difficult question.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that the Government must get through its legislation. We all understand that because that is the nature of the business of the Government and of the Parliament; nevertheless, we also have a responsibility to deal with the Bills and the mass of amendments in a way that is fair to all senators. Of course my particular interest is for the Opposition senators who have not had reasonable time to consider these matters in detail and who, in view of some pressure from their constituencies, are seeking that time. The Government can assume at least in my case, that if we have that extra degree of cooperation I will do everything in my power to expedite the final consideration of the package.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up the suggestion made by Senator Ray. If we look at the legislation and the recommendations emanating from the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, we see something like 30 packages of amendments on the table from the Government, the Australian Democrats or the Opposition. Of those I would imagine that only something like half a dozen are cause for any great dispute.
—That is your judgment.

—In reply to Senator Hill, those amendments have come up through the Joint Select Committee and most of them have been recommended unanimously by that Committee. I think the approach suggested by Senator Ray, that we consider those on which there is unanimous agreement, both within the Joint Select Committee and in terms of the Government responding positively to the recommendations of that Committee, could probably be adopted without any real danger of upsetting any honourable senator on the Opposition side
—You can push through whatever you like because you have the numbers but it will not result in good legislation or goodwill in this place.
—What I am suggesting in terms of good will is that we go through the parts that are not in dispute.
—What you say are not in dispute.
—I say they are not in dispute because, in our discussions in the past few days, there has been a fair degree of acceptance of the Government's positive responses.
—So far as I am concerned, and between Senator Macklin and yourself, but there are other senators in this place. That is the point I am making.
—I know that but the honourable senator should not say the discussions took place only between Senator Macklin and me, because he was involved in the discussions as well.
—I included myself. I said it.

—I do not know how we are to approach this matter. We have 33 packages of amendments all of which are responses to the Joint Select Committee's report. The Government has accepted something like 28 of them, in ballpark figures, and all of those amendments came up through the unanimous recommendations process of the Committee. If we bent backwards to accommodate Senator Hill we would be doing nothing but accommodating continual frustration at this stage. I say that, despite the conversations we have had in recent days, because the understanding we have had recently is that we would defer yesterday's consideration in order to ensure that we would have a cooperative approach to this legislation and the amendments today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say for the benefit of Senator Hill and other honourable senators that the Government proposes to bat on until lunchtime. —Order! Returning to where we were some time ago, the Committee has agreed to take the Australian Securities Commission Bill and the Corporations Bill together and as a whole. TALK.START.PARA: —I have been given various sheets of paper with lists on them. I have in my hand the one headed `Circulated amendments to be moved in Committee'. SPEECH.PARA: The objects of this Act are:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister's circular sets out heads of topic, and follows the Committee's report. There are other matters I wish to raise under the first part dealing with transitional provisions. It seems to me, therefore, to be appropriate within the scheme of what we are doing that they be dealt with now before we move on to the second of the Australian Democrats amendments under the heading, `Structure and Role of the Commission'.

—That is perfectly appropriate. I said at the outset that this was for guidance only and it was for the Committee to decide how we handle the matter. Is there any further discussion on transitional provisions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of matters I wish to raise with the Minister concerning transition. The Minister will be aware that the Committee itself expressed concern about the lack of transitional provisions. There is no doubt that the Government, despite its massive legislative package in this area, has not brought down a comprehensive transitional Bill which will allow for clear and unambiguous transition from the existing cooperative scheme to the Government's new proposed national scheme. There are specific and isolated instances within the legislative package that deal with particular matters. In response to the Committee's concern expressed generally as to the lack of appropriate transitional arrangements, the Government has simply referred to a few of the specific examples in which transitional provisions are included.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, there remain a number of important matters which should be teased out of the Minister in this area because, not surprisingly, the consequences of the transition can be vitally important to those who practise within this field, in fact, to all commerce and business in this country. The first matter that occurs to me in relation to transition is how the constitutionality will be tested. I think the business, legal and accounting professional communities would like the Minister to put on record how they are to be assured of the constitutional validity of acting under this new package of legislation which has, of course, received so much criticism as to its constitutional validity from so many eminent lawyers, including the Attorneys-General of all States in the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In raising this transitional problem Senator Hill has, as he said, detailed some of the points raised in the Joint Select Committee. The Government's position, however, is that there is no need for general legislative transitional provisions because in the Corporations Bill there are specific transitional provisions which continue in force and save the effect of things done under the cooperative scheme law, whether it is prospectuses, company charges, current investigations, prosecutions, liquidations and so on. Also, concerning the existing securities and futures industry, the Attorney-General, as recently as yesterday, made it very clear that transitional provisions would apply in all those areas, and do apply within the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: On the particular point of constitutionality, as we discussed last night in this place, the Government has no doubt about the constitutional basis on which it is acting. However, once again, the Attorney-General made it very clear that after royal assent and before proclamation there would be an opportunity for anyone who wanted to test the constitutionality of the legislation to proceed at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest, with great respect, that it is an incredible situation that the Government will pass this legislation, which has been questioned constitutionally by the Attorneys-General of all the States and the Solicitors-General of the States, yet says there will, of course, be an opportunity for anyone to test it. I put to the Government that if, significant parts turn out to be constitutionally invalid, the consequences will be calamitous for Australian business and industry. Is the Government not able to give the Committee some greater certainty as to how it proposes to test these critically important questions of constitutional interpretation? What will occur if an action is not brought?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Hill. The response given by the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, was quite extraordinary. I do not think it is possible to separate comments on the transitional arrangements from the constitutional situation because the length of time required for the transitional arrangements would be very heavily dependent on the amount of time it took to resolve the constitutional situation. I put it to Senator Bolkus that the response from the Government in the document tabled last Friday from which he has been quoting this morning is a totally inadequate response. There is no recognition in that response that the constitutional validity testing could go on for a very lengthy period. There seems to be some suggestion by the Government that somehow or other it will clear this up by having a quick test case. That is obviously sheer nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The constitutionality of the Government's proposals could run for years and it is just not credible for the Government to say that whilst all that is going on we do not really need transitional arrangements. What will be the situation so far as the confidence with which the securities and companies industries will be operating? Under what framework will they be operating? What will be the impact if the constitutional position is decided in one month as compared to one year, five years or 10 years? The Government's response does not answer those questions. The other important fundamental aspect about which the Government has not clarified its position-it certainly has not clarified it to my satisfaction or to my understanding-is: how will the constitutionality be tested and what will be the situation with the existing arrangements while that is being tested? What are the implications of one answer compared with another on that particular question? In other words, an enormous number of fundamental questions have not been answered let alone canvassed in the Minister's reply. I seek some greater clarification on that point because we are talking about a matter of great importance to investor confidence in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There may be a whole range of fundamental questions; there is also a range of fundamental answers. The most fundamental is that the Government believes this legislation is constitutionally valid.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Consumer Affairs to the fact that the Attorney-General's Department in its submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of this Parliament questioned the constitutional validity of this matter. I further ask whether those opinions have taken into account the concerns of the Law Institute of Victoria, which raised considerable doubts about several of the central elements of the Byers opinions, and whether those opinions deal with the range of matters that would nonetheless remain outside the ambit of the Commonwealth power even if the Byers opinions were upheld? In other words, a range of companies, from recreational to educational and scientific and health companies, would not be caught and would not be within the purview of the Commonwealth power. These would include charitable enterprises, holding companies, unincorporated associations, building societies and friendly societies. That is why it is critical to know what transitional arrangements there might be that will take account of the ongoing need for complementary State legislation. SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister: what arrangements have been entered into with the States in order to preserve the standing of those bodies that, even on the Byers opinion, will remain outside the corporations power? In order to appreciate the extent of any transitional arrangements it is necessary to know the stage that has been reached in Commonwealth-State negotiations. I ask the Minister to indicate to the Senate what stage those discussions have reached, if indeed they have commenced at all.

Certainly those who are employed by corporate affairs commissions (CACs) at present would have a very keen interest in knowing what stage negotiations have reached. Does the Minister propose that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) will be in a position to absorb all those people to take on board all their records? Are we to be told what sort of funding will be made available to the ASC, given that the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) was deliberately starved by this Government over a period of years? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that the case in view of the concerns expressed, in particular, by the Law Institute of Victoria? In a submission given in evidence to the Committee, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems clear that the question of whether a company is a trading corporation or a financial corporation as required under the Constitution paragraph 51 placitum XX will need to be determined on a case by case basis, even though the buyers opinion concedes that the ambit would not extend to recreational, scientific educational or charitable companies.
Further, its submission argued:

The proposition contained in the Byers opinion that a law which makes provision for the incorporation within the Commonwealth of trading and financial corporations is not necessarily one with respect to trading and financial corporations formed within the limit of the Commonwealth.

In other words, the Law Institute is saying that it is a dubious proposition to suggest that simply because a law makes provision for something, it is a law with respect to something. That might ultimately turn out to be the case, but I suggest that in many ways it is a novel proposition. It is one that needs to be tested. It is taking the definition to its extreme and I would have thought that the Government would certainly need the comfort of a second opinion.

In view of that submission from a respected body such as the Law Institute of Victoria, why has the Government not since sought a second opinion? The Law Institute submission became available only towards the end, and it is quite clear that it was a dead cat in the ring as far as the Government was concerned. I think it deserves an adequate answer. It needs a detailed response. It raises matters which are of genuine concern about the constitutional validity of a whole range of provisions which the Government would hope to be able to enact. After all, if one is talking about trading and financial corporations, one is talking about the vast bulk of companies operating in this country.

In its movements around Australia, the Committee heard evidence, in particular in Western Australia, about the very real concerns about what constitutes a trading and financial corporation. What happens when a dormant company is activated? What happens if a trading corporation becomes dormant? What happens to family companies that extend their activities? What happens if a company moves from a low level of passive investment to actively pursuing a range of commercial activities? It is not a simple matter to ascertain what constitutes a trading and financial corporation.

At what level does a company trade? If a company sells one item, is that trading? I recall, for example, appearing many years ago in a drug trafficking case in Victoria. My client had bought only $10 worth of marijuana for one of his friends, by request; he had not sought out the potential purchaser. He simply went to a hotel and got $10 worth and made no profit on the transaction, which was entirely isolated. His action was held to be trafficking. I find that a fairly radical proposition. If that is the case, one wonders what constitutes a trading activity of a corporation? Is it constituted by one isolated transaction? Does a company need a certain minimum level of financial activity before it is engaged in trading? What happens if it is a trading corporation and then ceases to trade? What happens if it becomes technically insolvent? Those are all matters which go to the heart of the concept of trading and financial corporations. To say that because a law deals with something it is a law with respect to it, is drawing a long bow. In effect, it would enable a government to pass any laws it liked simply because it touched on the subject matter. That simply cannot be so.

The Rocla Pipes case went a long way to establishing the extent of corporations power, but it clearly could not ever have intended that because a corporation was mentioned it should somehow come within the ambit of the power. One of the very real doubts in this area is what happens to companies that are formed within the limits of the Commonwealth. The States have always maintained that the Commonwealth jurisdiction would apply only once the company is up and running. That is why the States have been so keen to hang on to their ability to tax, by way of company registration fees and the like, new company registrations.

It simply cannot be the case that because a law deals with corporations it comes within the ambit of the power. Those propositions have been well established over a considerable period. If that is the case, I ask the Minister: why is it that when the Law Institute of Victoria raises a doubt about a central proposition of the Byers opinion the Government has not seen fit to seek a second opinion? Is the real answer that the Government is determined to push ahead with what the Minister chooses to describe as an accountability arrangement when, in fact, it is a grab for power, an attempt to ensure that the Government is in a position to dictate areas of responsibility? In other words, the Government objects to the diffusion of power. Those members of the Select Committee who issued a minority report regarded as very healthy the arrangement whereby the Ministerial Council was able to reflect a wide and diverse range of political opinions and to ensure that it was not possible for one Minister to make a decision-a decision that might well have been made on political grounds.

We have seen what happened in respect of the Commonwealth Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, in the lead-up to the last Western Australian election. He made pious and what I would describe as disingenuous suggestions that, somehow, it was a matter for the States to exercise the power to conduct a special investigation into the affairs of Rothwells, when the Minister knew well that the State Government of Western Australia had nothing further from its mind in the lead-up to that election. Clearly there are very real dangers when a power is vested in one government-one level of government-one individual, one department. I find it a matter of great concern that Senator Bolkus should be arguing that, somehow, so long as it is all within the control of one Minister, that is all that needs to be done.

In a sense, it is an extension of the Government's intellectual arrogance that it seems to have chosen not to seek further opinion when the Law Institute of Victoria makes it abundantly clear that that is a matter which deserves early resolution. Will the Minister now take account of that late submission from the Law Institute of Victoria and, indeed, address the matters raised by that body-matters which have not been raised even by Sir Maurice Byers himself by way of rebuttal? No doubt, that course has been open to the Government. No doubt, other opinions have been floating around in the public domain, as opposed to opinions commissioned by the Government, which could well have been re-presented to Sir Maurice who, no doubt, would be happy to turn his mind to those matters and rebut them as best he could. On the other hand, of course, he might concede that there were some matters to which he had not given proper consideration. In the interests of fairness and balance, it is highly desirable that the Government take account of all other respectable opinions and deal with them. After all, that is the nature of the game. When one is going to court one does not want the first quote one gets; one wants the best advice one can get. The Government has unlimited resources, when it chooses to use them, so its best course would be to go off and get a second opinion. If it chooses not to do so, the very least it can do is go back to the person expressing the first opinion and give him the opportunity to reconsider it. Will the Minister exercise either or both of those options and take account of some of the very real concerns that have been raised?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to his response to my earlier question and to what he said, as I understand it, in the second reading debate last night. I have not had a chance this morning to check the report of those remarks, but they relate to points similar to those that Senator Alston has been making. I will not go into all of those again in detail. I understood Senator Bolkus, in response to my earlier question this morning, to have said that the weight of legal opinion was that the legislation is constitutionally valid. Perhaps the Minister could take time from reading his newspaper. It is extraordinary that he should be doing so when we are debating what is probably not only the largest package of legislation ever introduced in this nation but also one of prime importance to the whole of the securities and companies industry and, therefore, the structure of the economy. It is disgraceful.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to know on what basis the Minister said last night, and said again this morning in response to my question, that the weight of legal opinion was that the legislation is constitutionally valid. He says that he has got the Byers opinion. We all know that even Sir Maurice Byers can be wrong-he got it wrong on the referendums, and there is every prospect that he is not correct here. But, more important, it is not correct to say that the weight of legal opinion favours the view that this legislation is constitutionally valid.

For months now we have had a unanimous view of the Solicitors-General of the States of Australia that there is very considerable reason for doubting the constitutional validity of this legislation. As Senator Alston has said, we have the view of the Law Institute of Victoria. Admittedly that Institute's submission came to the Joint Select Committee very late in the piece. However, it was not new; it had been around for some time. It was just that the Law Institute put it into detailed prose late in the piece. It represents the view of many reputable lawyers and other commentators with a legal background. As is said in the dissenting report of the Joint Select Committee, there are real doubts about the breadth of the corporations power. Senator Alston explained that in much more detail, so I will not go into it.

The point I am making is that, far from what the Minister has told the Senate-that the legal opinions came down heavily on the side of the view that the legislation is constitutionally valid-the opposite is the case. The whole thrust of the legal opinions that are available to the Senate is that the constitutional validity is in very real doubt. I want the Minister to tell us on what basis he made his statement last night, and again this morning, that the weight of legal opinion is towards supporting the constitutional validity of this legislation. I put it to the Minister that if he does not do that he will have misled the Senate and the Australian public. He has said that he has a firm basis for the constitutionality of the legislation. The whole thrust of the evidence before the Senate is that that is not correct. I therefore ask the Minister to explain how he reached that apparently quite incredible view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give short answers to all the points that have been raised. The Law Institute of Victoria did not raise anything that had not been anticipated by the Byers opinion. The Byers opinion was accepted unanimously by all parties in this Parliament two years ago in the deliberations of a Senate committee on the particular point of the constitutional validity of corporate legislation.

—Do I take it that the Minister is saying that he is not prepared to go back to Sir Maurice Byers for another quote, and that he is not prepared to go to the private profession to take account of concerns such as those expressed by the Law Institute of Victoria?
—We are prepared to go to the ultimate judge in this case-the High Court of Australia.

—Order! The Committee is considering the Bills as a whole and the question is that the Bills stand as printed. We have now passed Democrat amendment No. 1 and are discussing transitional provisions generally. If it is the wish of the Committee, we will proceed now to a general discussion of the structure and role of the Commission. Is that the wish of the Committee?

—No, it is not. I am still unclear as to what opinions the Government is relying on in coming to its view regarding the constitutional validity of this package. The Minister has said to us this morning that the advice is that it is constitutionally sound. Is the Minister relying solely on the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers, with which we are all familiar? Or is the Government relying on other opinions? If, so, what other opinions?

—The Government has worked on the basis of a firm belief in the constitutional validity of this legislation, emanating from the outside advice of Sir Maurice Byers and obviously from the belief within government that the legislation would be valid. We have also been encouraged along the way in our deliberations by the firm belief expressed by Senator Hill in the Senate Select Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs two years ago. Of course we would not proceed on the basis of Senator Hill's advice, no matter how eminent a lawyer he may be considered to be by some people in the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister, a little while ago, said to the Senate that the advice that was given by the Attorney-General's Department to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in relation to its inquiry headed The Role of Parliament in Relation to the National Companies Scheme was that a national scheme would be constitutionally valid. Although I do not have the submission of the Department at hand, I draw the Minister's attention to paragraph 4.35 of the Committee's report, which makes reference to the Department's submission and says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General's Department's proposal rests upon three assumptions. First, it assumes that the Commonwealth lacks the constitutional power to regulate the entire area covered by the scheme.

Now that we have clarified what in fact was the Department's advice to the Government at that time, I again ask the question that I asked earlier: has the Department changed its mind? Does the Department now believe that the advice that it gave to the Committee in 1987 was incorrect? On what basis has the Department changed its view on the constitutional validity of this package of Bills?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that that proposal at that particular time, before a committee of which both Senator Hill and I were members, was based on the premise that the Government did not have the power. It was not a firm belief expressed in an opinion that the Government did not have the power. The proposal was put up on the basis of `in the event'. That is where one could substitute `in the event' for the words `if it is assumed' in the evidence from the Department. `In the event' that the Government did not have the power is a question the answer to which it did not at that stage indicate to us in that part of its evidence. I think it is fair to say that not only did we have legal advice at the time but, as I said before-and I will say again continually, probably over the course of today, tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday-Senator Hill was one of those who were firm believers that we did have that power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that can be pursued much further. I do not know whether the Department has changed its mind, but clearly the Government has decided that it is politically useful to accept an interpretation that it will be constitutionally valid no matter what the consequences that might flow from that interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I go back to the question as to how this constitutional question will be tested. I remind the Minister of the letter of the Attorney-General of 29 April 1988 in which he notified State Ministers that he would not proclaim the legislation in the Bills package until a case determining the constitutional validity of the new scheme had been determined by the High Court. I repeat that part of the letter which was incorporated in the Committee's report:
The legislation will be introduced during the current Autumn Sittings of the Commonwealth Parliament but passage through the Parliament will not be sought until the Budget Session.
This is somewhat outdated now. It continued:

It is the Government's intention that, following passage, commencement of the legislation would be held back if it has become clear by then that a State or Territory Government proposes to initiate a comprehensive challenge to the constitutional validity of the legislation.
Is that still the position of the Government as incorporated within the letter of the Attorney-General dated 29 April 1988?

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that Senator Hill's question is whether the Government is still going to allow an opportunity for challenge?

—My question is whether it is still the intention of the Government, as set out in that letter, not to proclaim certain of the legislation in the Bills package until a case has been determined by the High Court.
—The Government's position is that the legislation will not be proclaimed until an opportunity has been given for people to raise a case in the High Court.

—That becomes critically important. For how long will the Government not proclaim the legislation to allow such a case to be taken? Is it facilitating a planned case? Have there been negotiations with the States in this regard? How will the case be brought? Upon what will it be based, there being no actions taken pursuant to the legislation because it is not proclaimed?
—Certain parts.
—The first question is: which parts will not be proclaimed and which parts will be proclaimed?

—The Government's position is that, when we get the legislation through, discussions will then proceed with the States on the basis of the legislation having passed through the Parliament. At that stage we will assess in those circumstances whether a challenge will be proceeded with. We will also be able to assess in those circumstances what degree of cooperation we can get from the States. In essence, the Government's firm position is that this legislation should be in place as soon as possible. But I am sure that if Senator Hill were ever able to switch to this side of the Parliament he would be able to work out that in terms of negotiating with States it is much easier if one has the legislation through Parliament than having it held up in the Senate.

—I am sorry to labour the point, but this proposal of the Government is unprecedented. What the Government is saying is that it will pass this massive package of legislation but not proclaim certain parts-we do not know what parts-until a case is taken, if it is taken, and that the Government will allow a period of time, the length of which we do not know, for that case to be taken. This is the basis upon which this Government is planning to set up the whole new legal structure for corporate and securities law in this nation. I think it is reasonable for the Parliament and the people of Australia to know which parts the Government will not proclaim, for how long it will not proclaim them and whether it has in place negotiations with the States for an action to be brought in the High Court.

—I hope, for Senator Hill's sake, that he gets that shadow ministerial switch that he may be seeking, to Foreign Affairs, because he has not really helped his cause this morning with that particular point. Before the Committee the point was made and evidence was adduced that this is not an unprecedented step. It has happened from time to time. In fact, evidence was produced to the Committee that it has happened four times. In four instances legislation has been allowed to be tested before a proclamation. So we are not dealing with an unprecedented situation. The basic point which we come back to is that once the legislation is passed the Federal Government will be negotiating--
—Where are the four precedents?

As I said, there were other instances adduced by way of evidence to the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation detailing other instances where there had been a deferred proclamation of particular parts of legislation. It is not anything new as the honourable senator might suggest.
—Which parts are you not going to proclaim?

—On that point, does the Government have in mind any particular period during which it will not proclaim the legislation? Is it going to leave it unproclaimed for a certain period and say, `This is the time during which we will give the States the opportunity to test the validity of the legislation'?

—The point I have been making for the last half hour or so has been that the time will be reasonable in the light of all the circumstances, one of which will be continuing negotiations with the States.
—What does that mean in practical terms? That is a nothing statement unless you can put something specific around it.

—It means precisely what I said. Depending on negotiations, we might proclaim earlier rather than later-but it could also be later rather than earlier. The firm position-which the honourable senator opposite understands full well, and I do not know why he does not address himself to it-is that once this legislation is through we are then in a different situation altogether in terms of discussing with the States how we can then proceed.
—Leverage, you mean?
—Constructive engagement is what we will be about.

—It rather sounds as though the Government reckons it has the States over a barrel, which may or may not be correct. Obviously we are not going to get a sensible answer out of the Minister on that one. Setting that aside, what about the prospect-which I would think is a very real prospect indeed-of other interested parties taking the matter to the High Court of Australia for testing? The honourable senator talks about negotiations with the States. We are aware from the evidence that was given to the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation that there was a very wide range of concern by a very wide range of parties and organisations in Australia, not just the States, about the constitutional situation. What proposals does the Government have in mind for the timeframe for the potential testing of the constitutional validity by parties other than the States?
—Cabinet's position is that we will not contest the issue of standing if any other party wants to bring the matter before the High Court of Australia.
—I do not quite understand that.

—I am surprised. What I said was that if any other people wanted to bring the matter to the High Court the Government would not contest their right to do so, their right of standing before the High Court.

I also return to the earlier point that Senator Hill in particular raised and that, I put it to the Minister, the Minister has not answered; that is, which parts of the legislation is the Minister talking about proclaiming? —I have already given the response a number of times that we will defer for an opportunity to be given for someone to take a matter to the High Court.

—Senator Hill may sit there and smirk. I have already answered that question. If Senator Hill had not been involved in other discussions he would not be raising the matter now.
