TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989, the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Bill 1989, the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Collection Bill 1989, the Wheat (Termination of Tax) Bill (No. 1) 1989, the Wheat (Termination of Tax) Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Wheat (Termination of Permit Tax) Bill 1989 and the Wheat Tax (Permit) Collection Amendment Bill 1989. The purpose of this package of Bills is to allow corporations to market wheat in the domestic market of Australia and to allow greater competition in the transport and storage of grains. Currently wheat marketing in Australia is regulated by the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 in conjunction with wheat and marketing Acts of the various States. These Acts are similar and grant to the Australian Wheat Board a monopoly over the marketing of wheat both internationally and domestically, with the exceptions of wheat sold under the permit system for stockfeed purposes, direct grower to buyer arrangements, and in Queensland where the State wheat board exercises domestic marketing powers.

SPEECH.PARA: In April 1986 the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport found that the current system was not the most efficient for meeting Australia's growing distribution needs, primarily because most grain was channelled along a restricted number of predetermined paths such as the compulsory use of rail for most grain transport. Also, prices charged for transportation and storage rarely reflect the actual cost of providing the services because bulk handling agencies pool the costs and charge growers an average price, resulting in all sorts of distortions. The thrust of the Commission's recommendations was that greater efficiency could be achieved through increased competition and the minimisation of storage, handling and transport service costs as well as port services and sea transport charges.

The Hawke Government would have us believe that it has been attending to the problems of the macro-economy and micro-economy of this nation. In fact it will claim that its macro and micro-economic reforms are in place. That is an absolute nonsense. All that the Government has been doing is talking about interest rates coming down and inflation. That is the macro-economy. In that area, all that the Government does is talk. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), particularly talks about it as an election approaches. The truth of the matter is, as the people of Australia now know, that under this Government those interest rates have risen regularly and repeatedly until they are now at a massive height. There is a very clear reason for that. The truth is that the Australian economy is sitting on the edge of an economic abyss. We could fall into that abyss, and the Australian dollar value would tumble to the detriment of us all. Australia has to keep paying interest on its overseas borrowings and it is borrowing more to make up for the annual $15 billion deficit. If the value of the Australian dollar falls, that problem increases exponentially in relation to the value of the fall. This Government is not attending to this matter at all, other than by maintaining the current dollar value by way of very high interest rates.

This is happening notwithstanding our receiving some of the highest commodity prices ever. Our overseas earnings are at their highest, but we are still going down the drain at the rate of $15 billion a year. Indeed, the revenue being earned by the booming tourism industry is also at its highest ever in this nation's history, yet we are still going down the drain at the rate of $15 billion a year. The Government has a major problem on its hands and it is not attending to that problem. All that the Government seems to worry about is winning the next election. As a result of the events of the past 36 hours, the Government has put that problem aside because there is no doubt that it will not run an early election now that we have Mr Peacock and Mr Blunt leading the coalition parties.

What could the Government do? As the Opposition parties have been pointing out to the Government for the past four or five years, one area in which it could take some action is micro-economic reform. That simply means enabling work to take place quicker and cheaper in the economy, overcoming some of the problems, the blockages that occur in this country, ensuring that there is adequate competition in order to keep prices down and ensuring that there is an adequate flow backwards and forwards of the business of this nation and that it is not hindered by work practices or State, Federal or local government regulations. These are areas in which there are difficulties. Let us not deny that in these areas there are difficulties for political parties. For instance, there is no doubt that the Government needs desperately to attend to the problems of the waterfront, coastal shipping and transport. Hundreds of millions of dollars could be saved if the Government would attend to those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are.

—The Government is not attending to those areas. It is talking a lot of rhetoric as it has done in the past, but the truth of the matter is that the Government is not prepared to confront the union movement with its work practices in those areas and take the action that should be taken to fix up these problems.

SPEECH.PARA: One area in which the Government says that there needs to be micro-economic reform and in which the Labor Party is prepared to take action is the domestic marketing of wheat. We agree that this is an area in which there needs to be micro-economic reform. However, we would say that it should not have anything like the high priority of the waterfront, the need to make changes in work practices in coastal shipping and in the transport industry. But no, the Government is not facing up to those areas. It is saying to the farmers, `Well, in your area, we are prepared to do something about it'. The problem for the farmers is that they, recognising that there is a need for micro-economic reform in the country and many of them recognising that there is a need for reform in their own industries, say that nevertheless the Government should fix up transport, coastal shipping and waterfront practices first or at least attend to them at the same time. I thoroughly agree with the suggestion that they should be done first and, if not first, at the same time.

Let me also say on behalf of the farmers that they are out in the world market. Their export activities, especially those of the wheat growers, are of such a nature that they are confronting world markets which are corrupted by governments subsidising farm produce therefore the prices that they are being paid for their product on the world market are not as good as they should be because, I repeat, of the corruption activities of other governments in the world interfering in these market activities.

Nevertheless, the Government says that its first priority in micro-economic reform will be wheat and wheat marketing. As I have said, until now, the Government's micro-economic reform program has been all rhetoric. It talks about it and will continue to talk about it. I have not the slightest doubt that the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who is in the chamber, will rise and tell us that this Government is in fact effecting some micro-economic reform on the waterfront and in coastal shipping. I say that that is nonsense, that what the Government is doing is gradually creeping up on the problem in such a way that it will take 100 years or more to achieve anything. It should stop going down the path at this snail's pace; instead, it should take this problem by the throat and throttle it. As I have said, the Government is saying that it will introduce micro-economic reform in wheat marketing. Why has it done that? It has done it because it knows that the Liberal and National parties represent wheat growers around Australia. The Labor Party does not. So, we have a political difficulty with our rural supporters. Nevertheless, we say to the Government, `All right. This country is in such desperate need of micro-economic reform that we are prepared to accept your proposal to enter into this area of reform in relation to wheat, subject to certain conditions. We recognise that area; so we will not be opposing this legislation'. The Hawke Government has been more concerned with attempting to divide the coalition and offering a sop to its own supporters and unions than adopting the Royal Commission's recommendations. In the process it has manipulated the media and, in particular, the Parliamentary Press Gallery so that there has been no reporting of the fundamental flaws in this package of legislation which is before us. The reasons for the serious reservations of wheat growers and some members of the coalition have been ignored by the Parliamentary Press Gallery which has accepted the Government's actions without any proper or real analysis of the major flaws in the legislation and the problems of the wheat growers.

A great deal of misinformation has been generated about this legislation. I do not know whether it is due to clever manipulation of the media or sloppy reporting, but the opponents of the legislation and the Government have certainly exploited it for their own ends. Where in the national media has there been any really informed comment on the issues involved in this legislation? Where in the media is the Government questioned about introducing legislation so sloppy that it requires 45 Government amendments to its laws? Surely any objective reporting would have raised these questions. The Minister might be embarrassed by the lack of foresight by his Department and the politicking of his Prime Minister.

Despite the Government's 45 amendments now put in place in the other House, there are still four major flaws in this package of legislation. The Government has failed to listen to and maintain consultation with the State agricultural Ministers, the Grains Council of Australia and the grain growers. This is the first flaw: since July 1988 the Minister has been talking about the necessity for complementary legislation. He has known that the Australian Wheat Board would not be able to trade intrastate on the domestic market after 1 July and that 80 per cent of the domestic market is carried out intrastate. To ensure competition it is essential that the Australian Wheat Board be a strong trader in this market. Unless the States move quickly the grain merchants could force the Wheat Board out of the domestic market.

The second flaw in this package of legislation is that the Government has had more than a year to persuade the States to carry this necessary complementary legislation but to date none has. No State, even those with Labor governments, has seen fit to introduce or pass the necessary complementary legislation. The Australian Wheat Board and the wheat traders are left in a position of considerable uncertainty about intrastate trade.

Thirdly, the legislation overrides the responsibilities of the State governments, which have prime responsibility for production and distribution within their boundaries. Fourthly, while part 7 of the Wheat Marketing Bill moves to provide some deregulation in powers in respect of the storage, handling, loading and unloading of wheat, including such facilities at ports and arrangements for the provision of storage, handling, transport and other marketing services together with proposed micro-economic reforms, it has not deregulated the labour market. That is, of course, putting the cart before the horse. We well know that this Government will not face up to its responsibilities in another area of micro-economic reform, that is, the deregulation of the labour market.

The Government's economic policies are abysmal. The car plan, for example, was an expensive failure. The Interstate Commission's report on the waterfront reveals the appalling state of that industry. The railway unions continue to impose huge inefficiencies on our railway systems. According to a Labor Party backbencher these inefficiencies will continue in Victoria. The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), in the Bendigo Advertiser on 19 April this year, said that V/Line would not lose out in any wheat plan. He assured the railway unions that their members would not lose any jobs and that there would be no redundant railway workers.

Australian flagships are overmanned and cabotage adds significant increases to our shipping costs. Most of the reservations of wheat growers would disappear if the Hawke Government put in place the necessary micro-economic reforms and complementary State legislation. The wheat growers are right to distrust the Hawke Government which is too weak to take the hard decisions. When has it made any tough decisions in recent months? All it is concerned about is trying to present some facade to the Australian people in relation to the next election which it anticipated it would call early in July. But the Labor Government will not be calling the election in July now. Now that the Liberal and National parties have changed their leaders the Labor Party will defer the next election for as long as it can.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would have done them anyhow.

—Of course we would have. The Minister claims that he is assisting the Australian Wheat Board to be more commercial and to be a strong trader, but the reality is that the legislation imposes more ministerial vetoes and the Minister knows the difficulty the Wheat Board would have in the domestic market under the legislation as proposed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Major amendments are needed to these Bills and I will be moving them in the committee stage. In outline, they are: a 95 per cent underwriting guarantee; a wheat grower chairman and five wheat growers out of the nominated eight people on the 11-person Board; provision for more say by the Grains Council of Australia in the spending and management of grain grower money which would be paid into the levy fund; deregulation of labour practices; and compensation for losses resulting from ministerial direction additional to that allowed for credit sales. I will be doing my best to make sure that the legislation contains provisions within it which would enable the Australian Wheat Board to be a strong intrastate domestic marketer of wheat.

The Government did not accept the Opposition amendment for harsher penalties for the illegal export of wheat but moved its own amendment which increased the maximum fine from $100,000 to $300,000. It also failed to accept amendments which deregulated the labour market. The Government is yet to face up to the harsh realities of Australian growers competing on world markets. The McColl Royal Commission has made out a persuasive case for restructuring but the Government has attempted to use this legislation for devious political purposes rather than as a means of genuine reform. The Bill, with the Opposition amendments, will mean a significant change for the Wheat Board, which will move from being a regulated receiver of wheat for domestic and industrial purposes to an active competitor in the domestic market.

There is also concern by some growers that there will be a return to the bad old days when marketing malpractices were common. That concern appears to me to be unjustified because trade practices legislation prevents the type of collusive practices by private traders which existed in the early decades of this century. Growers will still have the option of marketing their wheat through the Board. This aspect represents the big safeguard for farmers who do not wish to move into the marketing of their own grain at this stage.

The Government would have us believe that the 95 per cent underwriting proposed by the coalition parties would involve the Government in huge payouts. This is not true. If one looks back over the last 10 years at an estimated net pool return at the time of setting the guaranteed minimum price (GMP)-the guaranteed minimum would be set for one year instead of a three-year rolling average-one can see that only once during that 10-year period did the final price achieved by the Board go below the 95 per cent level. Is it not unreasonable for the wheat growers of Australia that we establish that minimum at 95 per cent? That one year in 10 was in 1980-81, before the Wheat Board was allowed to hedge on the futures market. At that time the guaranteed minimum price would have been $160.35. The Board achieved $140.88-$3.46 a tonne short of the 95 per cent.

In 1987-88 the guaranteed minimum price of $159.93 returned $163.50 and in 1986-87, the worst year for 15 years when it came to the Federal Government having to put money into underwriting, under this scheme the guaranteed minimum price would have been $125.72 and the return achieved $125.50-not below 95 per cent-and therefore there would have been no Government underwriting. TALK.START.PARA: —Some growers have expressed concern that in a deregulated domestic market the price could fall to an average export price, and the opponents of deregulation have played on this concern. I put it to the Senate that the evidence suggests otherwise. The 1984 Wheat Marketing Act allowed the feed wheat market to be deregulated, and a case has been cited to me of one Victorian grower who said he was $17 per tonne better off over his whole crop because he had been able to utilise his marketing skills rather than being forced to sell to the Australian Wheat Board. The then Bureau of Agricultural Economics made a study in New South Wales and found that on average growers were better off by around $13 per tonne if they marketed their own feed wheat.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two compelling reasons for deregulation of the domestic wheat market. The first is that the domestic market is, in effect, partly deregulated already. Secondly, it is only through allowing real competition on the domestic market that the efficiencies in storage, handling and transport that have been outlined by the McColl Royal Commission have any real chance of being achieved.

What are our options? Prior to 1984-85 growers had no opportunity to adopt a marketing strategy oriented to their individual situations. Under this legislation the grower has several marketing options-for example, pool cash-out, deferred payment and deferred delivery-and the grower should benefit from this increased range of marketing options. The McColl Royal Commission has estimated that there are savings to be made in the order of $10 per tonne over the whole crop if these efficiencies are implemented. Victorian Rail, which is currently subsidised at over $1 billion per annum to keep it operating, forces Victorian wheat growers to use their own trucks, and prohibits the use of other road transport to truck wheat more than 60 kilometres.

Union influence recently resulted in a small Victorian grain receival depot at Laharum which had been receiving 60,000 tonnes per annum and which previously had special dispensation being closed down at the behest of the Australian Railways Union. This forced growers to truck their wheat north to Murtoa or Horsham, thus increasing the distance to the port of export, Portland, by at least 60 per cent. In other words, they had to truck their wheat north to put it on a train to take it south. That is the nonsense that goes on because the Government will not address deregulating the labour market. The Australian Wheat Board in that case was powerless to intervene. Under this legislation and last year's amendment there is more flexibility.

The railways must get their act together. A recent Industries Assistance Commission report claimed that productivity improvements of 100 per cent were possible in State rail authorities, and there was a potential for labour productivity increases of up to 70 per cent and cost reductions of 30 per cent. Rail should be the most efficient way of transporting bulk grains. The fact that it is not is an indictment of our railways and their employees who have sheltered behind the monopoly they have enjoyed at the expense of the growers. Over the past 10 years the cost of transportation, handling and loading of wheat into ships has trebled, while growers are receiving no more than they did 10 years ago.

Currently only one-quarter of our commodity exports leaves our shores in a substantially, or even partially, processed form. It is estimated that only 28 per cent of our total exports are made up of value added products. By contrast, the figure for the United States of America is 33 per cent, for Canada 44 per cent and for the United Kingdom 62 per cent. This low value added level is reflected in a decline in our food export performance. While our volume of food exports has increased over the past 10 years, our share of the world food trade has fallen by more than 30 per cent.

There are major new opportunities for value added foods, particularly on the Asian market, as Asian populations become more urbanised and their tastes more westernised. These include prepared meals, biscuits, breakfast cereals and soups. While this is a developing section of the Australian food industry, our industry tends to fall well behind its counterparts in Japan, the United States of America, the United Kingdom and eastern Europe. Deregulation of the domestic market will provide great opportunities and incentives to develop such value added food exports and should result in new industries springing up. I certainly hope it does.

The worst case scenario is that the Australian Wheat Board would be involved only in exports. That is still 80 per cent of the crop and would enable the Board to continue to dominate the market overall, thus enabling the Board to maintain a floor price in the market. Providing the Wheat Board continues to perform competitively and efficiently-and there is no doubt that it has in the past, and no reason why it should not in the future-it should easily retain its status as the dominant local marketer of Australian wheat. There is a natural concern that the Hawke Government will not live up to its part of the bargain, but a change of government will rectify that. The opening up of the domestic market to competition should, under a new Liberal and National Party government, be of major benefit to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a set of Bills containing the most significant changes to orderly wheat marketing since 1947. This set of Bills is divisive not only among the 45,000 wheat growers around Australia but also among members and senators on both sides of this Parliament. It is interesting to note that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, according to my information, had only 41 per cent of his own Caucus backing him on this issue. But in his usual arrogant fashion he rammed this legislation through just as he did with the dairy plan which cost each Western Australian dairy farmer $12,000 a year. Mr Kerin brought his troops into line in the usual way in the Australian Labor Party Caucus. Ask Mr George Georges how it works, or my own representative, Mr Campbell, who incidentally has his own views on this debate but is hardly likely to try his luck twice.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the original plan came into effect in 1947 after 15 years of agony, bankruptcy and general walk-off from properties that started in 1931. I hope I may be excused for going back into history. Some people like going back into history and some do not. The ones who do not have a good reason for not doing so. As I said, 1930 was the time when farmers were encouraged to grow more wheat, to improve Australia's trade in the world sphere. Such trade is even more important today. The Government was also advocating the opening up of more land for two reasons. One was to settle returned soldiers from World War I, the other was to settle `turned down' miners, miners who could not get a ticket to work underground any more. After wheat growers were encouraged to plant more wheat, and agricultural banks and intending buyers loaned them money, the wheat buyers took over. Between them, the banks and the buyers fragmented the prices-forced them down-and the growers did not even get enough to cover advances. After growing crops in difficult conditions the growers owed money to the buyers.

The results were massive walk-offs, broken families and suicides. Farmers were thrown off their properties and even gaoled for selling wheat to the local storekeeper in exchange for stores to feed their family. If this debate had not started so suddenly I would have brought with me a book outlining the history of my own district-Southern Cross-in Western Australia, where a farmer was actually gaoled for that reason. The battle to get an equitable marketing system continued for 15 years. It finally came to fruition in 1947-incidentally, under a Labor government. I am proud to say that at the time my father was a foundation member of the Western Australian wheat growers union.

A pooling system was used during the war because wheat was needed to feed the troops. It showed people what a pooling system was capable of achieving. A referendum of growers was conducted in 1947, and 64 per cent voted for orderly marketing and an underwriting procedure in the system. Speculators then had to move elsewhere. In turn, they wrecked lamb and wool prices, until wool prices were stabilised under the wool stabilisation scheme adopted in 1973.

As I said, this plan involves many changes. The main ones are: Deregulating the domestic market; changing the guaranteed minimum price system; and changing the structure of the Wheat Board. I will address each change in that order. Five years ago, when the last plan came into effect, two permit systems for domestic wheat were introduced. One was the feed wheat permit, whereby one simply rang the Wheat Board, received a permit by phone, and sent money for the research levy and the administration levy. Under that system the wheat changed hands, and so did the money. A grower to buyer permit was also introduced. A deal was reached between the two parties, but the payment was via the Wheat Board, with a guarantee of payment to the grower. The grower immediately received the premium and participated in the pool. As this system is being eliminated, the cheque in the mail feature could be a problem because there will be no guarantee of payment for industrial and milling wheat.

All these changes have been introduced by this Minister in his micro-economic reform fury to deregulate the industries that generally support the conservative parties, yet he will not tackle his own mates on the waterfront and in the rail unions, including grain handlers. His excuse to move was the report of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. Mr McColl pointed out that there could be a saving of between $10 and $12 per tonne if certain measures were put into place. McColl recommended the deregulation of transport, handling, storage, and the waterfront. He also said that this could be done under the present marketing system.

I now turn to the infamous waterfront, where rort upon rort is perpetuated. There are no rorts in the wheat industry. On the waterfront, grain handlers earn up to $78,000 a year for an average 46-hour working week. Mainly, they watch self-loading ships load. The average waterfront worker earns $1,000 a week for a 28-hour working week. There are 2,000 too many waterside workers, and many continue working beyond a reasonable working age. There is rort upon rort. As I have mentioned, McColl said that savings could be made without changes to the marketing system. Because the Industries Assistance Commission made a minor recommendation that the wheat marketing system could be deregulated, the Minister is proposing to deregulate industries that support the conservative parties. He went in boots and all. If, as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said, the domestic market has been deregulated for the last five years-I refer to the two permit systems that I have already mentioned-it would have been far simpler to extend the feed wheat permit across the board. One could simply ring the Board and get a permit over the phone. One could set one's own price, delivery terms, and mode of transport-if one's State deregulated the transport system.

It is ironic that under this legislation the levy for research is still to be collected. I cannot see how it will be collected properly if there is no contact with the Wheat Board, even by phone, under the deregulated system. How will it be enforced? I do not know. It may be slightly easier to collect from the larger buyers of feed wheat, industrial and milling wheat, who are located all over Australia. I suppose they will be subject to raids as there are provisions in the Bill dealing with those who do not pay the levies. I believe that it is an impossible system and the loser will be the research arm of the wheat industry. As I said, a simple phone permit system would have been accepted by growers.

I support the deregulation of transport, storage and handling, as I have done for many years. Authorities such as the various bulk handling authorities are well placed to take competition. The newest bulk handling authority is in South Australia-it was incorporated in about 1961. The silos have been built mainly with grower finance and they are in a position to take some competition. It will take at least 20 years for any private company to build such a system. But the cooperatives that set up the bulk handling authorities are servants of their shareholders, and I think they should get rid of some of their sweetheart deals with the unions. I refer, for example, to Cooperative Bulk Handling Ltd of Western Australia and the deal it had with the Australian Workers Union at Kwinana. Later, after a six-week strike, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia took over anyhow.

The Minister has ridden roughshod over 95 per cent of wheat farmers around Australia. I attended meetings all over Western Australia. I was invited to attend meetings in Victoria, but I could not get to them. Out of a total of 800 farmers who attended the meetings that I attended, only 10 voted in favour of deregulating the domestic market. I am assured that upon opening up the domestic market farmers can use their own marketing skills. I am sure they can; the few who are selling privately now are doing so. What must be remembered is that there will be many more sellers in the market and many others with marketing skills. I, for one, will be competing for some of those stockfeed and chicken farm deals. From now on, the odd few looking for deregulation will not have it on their own. This will lead only to one thing-lower domestic prices. This Minister is in the minority in his own party, as he received only 41 per cent support for this proposal in his party room; honourable senators opposite have not queried me on that point to date. He even tried to deregulate the export market. He has not succeeded this time but this is an attempt to get a foot in the door. We will be debating that matter in a few years time-if he is still the responsible Minister, which I doubt-when he tries to wreck that system also.

My friend Mr Mick Gayfer, who is Chairman of Western Australian Cooperative Bulk Handling-I should say that he was my friend until I opposed him for his upper House seat in 1986; I still call him a friend but I do not know whether he recognises that friendship now-said that the permit system would lead to total deregulation of the market. He was right because this system provides a foot in the door for the Minister for further deregulation. I point to the New Zealand experience where the domestic market was deregulated a few years ago. The result was a drop in price of about $NZ100 per tonne and now there is virtually no wheat board. However, my Party has decided to support domestic deregulation under certain conditions-these are cornerstone conditions, and I support them-which include: reasonable progress towards deregulation in the transport, handling and waterfront areas to reduce the many cost burdens placed upon wheat growers by high levels of regulation, restrictive work practices and anti-market abuses in those areas; a 95 per cent underwriting guarantee to provide a satisfactory first advance or cash trading option for the Wheat Board-this is the major cornerstone on which we will fight to the end-the maintenance of the Wheat Board's existing powers in relation to exports, which I have already mentioned; and the Board having the capacity to remain a strong trader competing on fair and reasonable terms with other domestic traders.

On 3 May 1989 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) addressed a meeting of the Australian Mining Industry Council, at which I was present. The Labor Party was so arrogant about this Bill that the night before it was debated in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister told the Council that the Government had deregulated the domestic marketing of wheat. He then went on to say that he would do something about coastal shipping. If this legislation is passed, we will see how the Government will go about deregulating the waterfront, the rail unions and coastal shipping. Coastal shipping has already replied; the Waterside Workers Federation has told us that in no uncertain terms what it will do; and the rail unions of Victoria have also told us what their ideas are.

So far the Government has said that it will override the States on the question of the bulk handling-that is quite easy as it is grower controlled- and rail systems, which will not be quite so easy because of union control. Since 1982 I have led the fight against Westrail on the question of grain freights. Growers in the long haul areas were being ripped off in a captive market because they could not use their own transport. The regulations say that it is quite okay for growers to use their own transport, but if a grower is 370 miles from the port I do not think he can cart his own wheat as it is harvested to the port without building expensive on-farm storage. If the crop is any good he will battle to get it away to the local silo.

Some road competition in short haul soon convinced Westrail to drop its freight in that area. Over the years some gains were made in Westrail freight charges, but there are lot more to be made. Under this legislation I believe that Westrail will have a dual system of grain transport especially on the longer hauls. Export wheat will be deregulated, so I presume that the freight rate will be cheaper. If a grower wants to transport feed wheat to a miller in Perth, then I assume that it will not be deregulated and I presume that more will be charged for it. I do not know what will happen, but that is where we could quite easily be heading. I presume if that happens the forwarder will have to sign a statutory declaration to say whether it is export wheat or feed wheat to be used in Australia.

Will this Government tackle the waterfront, coastal shipping and the rail unions? The rail unions have already told us of their position. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, had the hide to tell the House of Representatives that the Government had to decide what was best for the growers. I heard him myself. He knew that only about 5 to 7 per cent of the Australian wheat growers want him to interfere with the wheat market, but he told us that the Government knew better and that it had to make the decision. He went on to say-honourable senators should listen to this-that the unions do not tell the Government what its industrial policy will be. I would like to know what Mr Kelty thought about that. This Government will cave in to the unions as usual. Last week I personally heard Mr Kerin tell the House of Representatives that the industry, which holds a 95 per cent view to the contrary, does not know what is best for itself and that the Government must take over. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy refused to attend any of the protest meetings around Australia. Once again, he knew better. This Government does not practise what it preaches.

I will now come to the most significant aspect of the Opposition's conditions; that is the guaranteed minimum price (GMP). The GMP purpose is twofold: firstly, to guarantee a minimum price to stop sudden world downturns in price being reflected on the Australian market and, secondly, to enable the Government to guarantee the borrowings of the Wheat Board enabling the Board to pay a reasonable first advance. Now the Minister has decided that only the subject year forecast be used. In other words, instead of a three-year average, there will only be a subject year figure average. The Minister intends to bring that down to 90 per cent, phasing down to 80 per cent and ceasing altogether after five years. He told us that a revolving fund should be used, as it is in wool. I assure the Senate that it works with wool because we are the big players in the world and we control wool and world prices. In Australia we do not control wheat prices or wheat movement because we have only 11 per cent of the world market. Wheat cannot be stored indefinitely as wool can because of insect problems and the enormous volume of space required.

In a deregulated domestic market the result will be that the domestic price-which is set at best export price, after all Australian consumers have the best wheat available-will settle at the average export price. Of course, the average export price is already affected by the United States enhancement program whereby the Government has been subsidising sales to Russia to the tune of $15 per tonne. As I said, this has already had enough effect on our export wheat without adding injury to the internal market as well. That is why the coalition demanded in return for deregulation on the domestic market an assurance of 95 per cent GMP and without the phasing down option. This is vital because that is the figure that the domestic market will settle at. I exhort the Australian Democrats to support us on this point.

Furthermore, there will be no cushioning effect. Under the old system there was a cushioning effect averaging over three years. If world prices went down suddenly Australian prices would be held up and they would decline more steadily. On the other side of the coin, if world prices jumped faster the price in Australia would have gone up more slowly. Under the old system the Government made up any shortfall. That happened only once in 41 years and that was in 1986. In the case of a disastrous downturn under the new system, the Government will have to look at other measures to assist growers. I hope that that never happens, but I wish Mr Kerin would be more definite. If the removal of the floor GMP succeeds it will be the final insult to our 45,000 wheat growers because they have to buy their supplies from regulated and monopoly markets. I have in mind fuel, machinery, chemicals and most imported fertilisers. As the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is a wheat grower, I wonder what his private thoughts are on this matter. I have heard his own brother and partner state his position in Western Australia time and time again.

I now move to the composition of the Board. There has been a vast change. Under section 15 of the Bill it is proposed that the Board consist of a chairperson, a managing director, a government member and eight nominated members from persons nominated by the selection committee. I cannot accept the fact that the chairperson does not have to be a wheat grower at the time of taking office. Also, there is no specification that each wheat growing State shall have representation. I find that I cannot accept that either. If this Senate, which is a protector of the States, does not support each State having a representative, then I believe that it is failing miserably.

Getting back to the chairperson, it is scandalous that that person does not have to be a full time wheat grower. This industry has kept Australia afloat with respect to its balance of payments. It has kept export balances somewhere in perspective for the last 60 years. The industry will net somewhere near $4 1/2 billion this financial year and may even return to its position as Australia's second biggest income earner behind wool, ousting coal from that position.

I reaffirm that the composition of the Board is an insult to the industry. It is like the Government installing a non-mining man to the chair of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-not that the Government has the power to do so, but if it had it would be a similar case. In the debate I have heard in this place and read of in the other place, very little mention has been made of the damage to Australian growers caused by the sale of subsidised American wheat to Russia. As I mentioned previously, Mr Quayle visited Australia in the past few weeks and made a few remarks about the problems, brushing off Senator Gareth Evans. As soon as he left the country there was another big sale of $1.5m tonnes at a great discount to Russia. This Government has made only piteous efforts to correct the situation for growers who each pay $9,000 per year to subsidise Australian manufacturers because of the situation with respect to tariffs on imports. Farmers are tired of being treated like fools. In the transport industry, farmers pay 120 per cent recovery for the use of VicRail, for instance, while urban dwellers pay only 35 per cent recovery for urban rail. I question proposed section 63 (3) which `enables the Board to attribute to transferred wheat'-I presume to the next pool-`such sale price as the Board thinks appropriate.' I want some answers on this point.

I reiterate the arrogance with which the wheat growers of Australia have been treated. Caustic comments have come from various speakers in this place and the other place. There has been personal vilification of speakers who have defended the situation. A good example of that was Mr O'Keefe's taking to task of Senator McGauran, which involved personal vilification. Instead of referring to what Senator McGauran said about wheat, he went into his record at university. What has anyone's record at university or in any other part of life got to do with what he said in debate? Mr O'Keefe should think twice before he makes other accusations, because his own escapades may not measure up too well before his electors.

As I said earlier, my Party has taken a decision to accept deregulation of the domestic wheat market. I have always fought for the decision to be made by the industry itself-in other words, for self-determination. This was our policy before the last election, but it has since been reviewed. My Party and the National Party came to an agreement to accept the new plan subject to the four conditions I mentioned earlier. I will vote with my Party at the second reading stage, though with some pang of conscience, having regard to my family's plight and fight in the 15 years from 1932 to 1947.

I will support all the amendments moved by our side of the Senate. I hope they will be supported by the Australian Democrats, especially the guaranteed minimum price amendment. As I said, it is a cornerstone. If the GMP amendment is not accepted by the Government, we will be in trouble. Just five years ago when the last plan was formulated, I was active in agro-politics. I was not then in this place and did not dream I would be here for this plan. A lot of water has gone under the bridge since 1983 and the two permit systems made the wheat plan work very well. It is unfortunate that we are introducing this legislation so hastily, but if the cornerstone conditions are accepted and put into action we can make good legislation.

The wheat industry is an important industry throughout Australia, providing $4 1/2 billion in export income which is greatly needed in Australia at present. Without those conditions being accepted, we will go into chaos. I do not want to see happen again what happened so many years ago, but I had to mention something of the history of it. As I said, only time will tell the wisdom of this plan and time may yet prove that my fears were well founded.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate today we are debating the Wheat Marketing Bill and six associated Bills. It is a matter of common knowledge that this topic has greatly exercised the collective minds of the coalition parties for almost 12 months, since the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, first began talking-I repeat `talking'-about this matter last year. At that stage Mr Kerin had in no way indicated conclusively what he would eventually propose to do by way of legislation. Indeed, as we all know, Mr Kerin's formal proposals in legislative form were not introduced to the House of Representatives until 13 April this year. Meanwhile, Mr Kerin made a number of statements indicating his intentions, all of them, I think it is fair to say, of a uniformly hostile kind, towards the wheat growers of Australia, the wheat industry in its institutional forms in this country, any State Government or Minister of agriculture in a State government who dared in any way to differ from Mr Kerin's views on the matter, and anybody who was not prepared to give assent to whatever Mr Kerin's view, stated at the time, might be.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate on this Bill, which has now come to the Senate after processing in the House of Representatives last week, as far as I am concerned, is a debate not just about the important topic of wheat, important though that topic is. It is also about how we happen to have arrived at the situation in which we now find ourselves. In that sense, it has to be acknowledged that it is a debate in part-indeed my Liberal Party senatorial colleague, Senator Panizza, has just been referring to some of its aspects-about the procedures within the coalition which have resulted in the present state of the legislation. I will come back to some aspects of that.

To begin with, I want to say that, to the extent that I am known in this country, I imagine that most people who know me or think they know of me would probably associate me with a lifetime in the Commonwealth Public Service and in the Commonwealth Treasury and, more recently, with some other more adventurous occupations. But I remind the Senate and those people that I actually grew up on a wheat farm in Western Australia, not all that very far from the present abode of my senatorial colleague, Senator John Panizza, who has just been speaking. My father, who is dead now, took up his small property between Merredin and Bruce Rock in Western Australia in about 1928 or 1929. I was born in 1929. My parents lived through the Depression in the wheat farming industry in the 1930s, some aspects of which Senator Panizza referred to. While I am not one of those who believe that it is appropriate to live in the past, to spend one's time looking back to those very sad, and in some cases almost desperate, days for the wheat industry and for individual wheat farmers-that serves no useful purpose-I want it to be clearly on the record that I, of course as a child, had some personal acquaintance with the situation in which wheat farmers found themselves at that time.

At this stage I want to foreshadow that, on behalf of myself and my National Party colleagues, I shall be moving an amendment to the second reading motion. In due course I shall cause that amendment to be circulated to honourable senators. The substance of my amendment will be to the effect that the Senate should deplore the Government's betrayal of the wheat farmers of Australia; condemn the Government for weakening the position of the Australian Wheat Board as a strong trader in the domestic wheat market; and regret the Government's failure to negotiate adequately with State governments over their respective responsibilities, including those in regard to State statutory marketing authorities.

The history of this matter has of course gone through a number of phases. I have referred already to Mr Kerin's original ambiguous, and at times ambivalent, proposals, including his proposal to strip the Australian Wheat Board of its powers not merely in respect of domestic trade in wheat for human consumption but also in respect of wheat for export, which of course constitutes something like 80 per cent of the Australian crop This is an area of operation in which I think it is fair to say the Australian Wheat Board has been conspicuously successful. It is certainly one in which it has earned the regard, admiration and professional respect of international wheat traders and of other countries and their representative organisations with which it does business.

Let me say-in these matters, I do not want to sail under false colours-that on the question of the precise degree of regulation of the Australian wheat market I probably hold less strong views than do some of my party colleagues and some others in the community, including people in the wheat farming community. I have never made any secret of that fact. My view of the Bill, as it was originally introduced in the House of Representatives, is based, as I said a moment ago, not only on its actual terms so far as it affects the wheat industry but also on the manner in which we in the coalition parties have subsequently adopted an attitude towards it.

Let me go back for a moment. It is a matter of record that there was a long process of discussion within the coalition parties on this matter. As is again well known, that discussion resulted eventually in the setting up of a committee of six people to draw up what I suppose the lawyers might call a heads of agreement document, which purported to set out the coalition's attitude towards deregulation of the wheat industry. I should like to refresh the memories of honourable senators by referring to what that document says. I will not read it in full because it runs to almost a page of print. After referring, among other things, to the present problems confronting our wheat industry because of the extreme corruption in world wheat markets, resulting from, in particular, the activities of the European Community, and also-admittedly partly in response to that-the activities of the United States, through the export enhancement program--

TALK.START.PARA: —They did it again.

—As my colleague Senator Brownhill reminds me, in the case of the United States there was a specific action under the export enhancement program arrangements only a few days ago, to which not only the Government but also the Opposition have taken very strong exception. Having referred to that preliminary aspect of this heads of agreement document, it then said this about the then position of the coalition:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition believes that complete deregulation of the domestic wheat market-
I repeat, `complete deregulation of the domestic wheat market'-
should proceed in conjunction with-
there follow four points-what might be called preconditions-

reasonable progress towards deregulation in the transport, handling, storage and waterfront areas to reduce the many cost burdens placed upon wheat growers by high levels of regulation, restrictive work practices and anti market abuses in those areas;
a 95 per cent underwriting guarantee to provide a satisfactory first advance or cash trading option for the Wheat Board;
the maintenance of the Wheat Board's existing powers in relation to exports; and
the Board having the capacity to remain a strong trader competing on fair and reasonable terms with other domestic traders.

That heads of agreement document was placed before the coalition joint party room on 4 April and was agreed to by all concerned. I think it is fair to say that, as with a good many such agreements in the world of politics, it probably did not satisfy any person on all points but, like all such documents, it was an agreement that had been hammered out after long and properly conducted discussions between those responsible for framing it. In the case of the National Party, those people were my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr Bruce Lloyd, the shadow Minister for primary industry; my senatorial colleague Senator David Brownhill; and Mr Michael Cobb, the honourable member for Parkes. As I have said, that document was agreed to. On 13 April-nine days later-Mr Kerin introduced his legislation. If I may say so, that legislation is something wonderful to see. I will come back later to its quality. It was introduced in this place after deliberations by the Minister lasting almost 12 months. On 13 April it was agreed to-by processes which I will not traverse. Most unfortunately, I was not in Parliament on the afternoon of 13 April. As you, Madam Acting Deputy President, will recall, the Senate rose at about lunchtime that day to go into Estimates committees. As those did not concern me, I thought that I would be very clever and evade the terrorism of the air traffic controllers at Sydney Airport and get back to Queensland. I caught a flight out of here at 3 p.m. and thought how clever I had been.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the one stop Qantas air route from Sydney to London via Bangkok which involves flights over Pakistan and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, among other countries. Is the Minister aware of an incident in which a Qantas 747 en route to Australia reportedly was forced to land by Pakistan air authorities in Karachi in order to identify itself as it flew over highly sensitive air space bordering Afghanistan? Does Qantas Airways Ltd intend to alter its flight path over this region in view of the fact that the Pakistani Air Force had shot down two Afghan and/or Soviet jets in the same air space only days before the incident and in the light of the tragic Korean Air and Iranian air-bus incidents? Was this Karachi landing an isolated incident or have there been other similar incidents? Does Qantas take special precautions against trigger-happy fighter pilots when flying near areas of hostilities, for example, the Middle East, to protect aircraft and passengers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the incident involving a Qantas aircraft being asked to land in Karachi on 8 November last year. The incident involved the regular scheduled Qantas flight en route from London to Bangkok which was delayed departing London by 24 hours as a result of extreme weather conditions over Europe.

ANSWER.PARA: Shortly after being given permission to enter Pakistan air space, Karachi air traffic control (ATC) sought details of the aircraft's overflight clearance. Although the captain gave full details surrounding the circumstances of the delayed flight, Karachi ATC advised that the aircraft had no clearance to overfly Pakistan and asked it to land in Karachi for identification or return to London. The captain, under the circumstances, elected to land at Karachi.

As soon as the aircraft landed it was cleared to proceed on the advice of British Airways, the company's agent in Pakistan. No official contact was made with the captain and as a result he received no explanation as to why his explanation of the circumstances of the delay was unacceptable.

Subsequent to the incident, Qantas relayed its view to Pakistan aviation authorities that the authority granted by Pakistan to Qantas to conduct services on the route in question allowed delayed services to operate to their normal routing. The airline has had no advice from Pakistan authorities to contradict this view, which the Australian Government supports. Naturally, the Australian Government was concerned at the incident, although it needs to be stressed that at no time was the aircraft or its crew in danger. The Government has made representations to the Pakistan Government to convey its concern about the diversion and the fact that the captain was not interviewed or given an explanation by Pakistani authorities.

The Pakistan Government has explained that the diversion request was made because of uncertainty in the minds of Pakistan air traffic control as to whether the aircraft had an overflight clearance. It is clear finally that the incident is an isolated episode, albeit an unfortunate one and one that is most unlikely to recur. While causing inconvience, obviously, to Qantas and its passengers, I stress again that there was at no time any danger to the safety of passengers or crew.

Senator Maguire asked me a more general question at the end of his question about safety generally in flying in areas where there are nearby hostilities. I will seek some further information of a supplementary kind and will respond to him on that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter gave me some notice of this question, although it was fairly late. I have done my best to obtain some information in the short time available to me. Senator Coulter did provide copies of some correspondence. I am having some checks made to find out whether that is all the correspondence that is involved.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the third part of the question, certainly I am aware of a pollution problem at Port Pirie. TALK.START.PARA: —Points for geography.

—I am glad to get points for something! I am told that since 1986 South Australia has regarded the waters of Spencer Gulf as an internal matter. Clearly, the Commonwealth does not have power to control marine pollution within South Australian internal waters.

But I will undertake to get some more details of the exchanges between the Fraser Government and the South Australian Government. If, as a result of that search for information, there is anything more to tell the honourable senator, I shall certainly do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

I ask whether the Minister is aware of article 1 of the London Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, to which Australia is a signatory, which says:

and that is the significant word-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I announced some new figures on Australian tourism only last week. Quite obviously Tasmania has the potential to develop a very significant overseas tourist industry. Obviously Tasmania has some unique attractions. Perhaps the Gray Government would have better served Tasmania by promoting those magnificent forests and wilderness areas rather than attempting to chop them down and develop them on each and every occasion. That natural beauty and wilderness is obviously the way for Tasmania to go. The benefits to the Tasmanian economy if this were to happen would be enormous.

As an example of the Commonwealth's desire to help Tasmania, a desire upon which the Prime Minister expanded a couple of days ago in another place, it is appropriate for me to tell Senator Aulich and anyone else interested that the Federal Government will give $30,000 on a dollar for dollar basis for a three-month consultancy to investigate ways in which Tasmania can better benefit from the great interest being shown in Australia by overseas tourists.
