QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REACTION TO SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY STATEMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Following the release of the Government's science and technology statement on Monday, can the Minister inform the Senate what the reaction has been to the statement and, in particular, is he aware of any serious criticisms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reaction to the Government's statement varies between mildly favourable and very favourable. I put in the mildly favourable category the comments of the vice-chancellors and the comments of the Institution of Engineers, for example, who have said that this is a very good start and that more needs to be done over time.
—Oh!
—Senator Lewis scoffs. The other category of comment, which I describe as highly favourable, came from certain officers of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation--
—Ha, ha!

—Yes, it does, including the Chief Executive, and from a variety of others. Indeed, the press comment on the science program announced on Tuesday was generally favourable. I was asked by Senator Childs particularly whether I was conscious of any serious or adverse criticism of the package announced by the Government. I am aware of two examples of very serious criticism because the condition of the people who made them can be described only as serious, if not terminal, if there is a reshuffle on the Opposition benches. The first criticism came from the Opposition spokesman on education, Mr Julian Beale, and the Opposition spokesman on science, Mr McGauran.

ANSWER.PARA: In a press release put out after the Government's statement Mr Beale indicated his complete lack of understanding of the policy initiatives behind the Prime Minister's Science Council. He said it would compete with the Australian Research Grants Committee and the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) for the disbursements of funds. The Council has nothing to do with that function. It is a coordinating body to bring together the various peak bodies and the scientific expertise in the country to plan and develop forward programs. Mr Beale concluded with a most revealing remark in the halcyon days that we have had this week:
Under the verbal camouflage the clear message is this that this Government believes that there are no votes in science.

That is the message with which Mr Beale concludes. That seems to be a clear indication that it is Opposition policy, if Mr Beale has his way, to pursue policies related only to winning votes rather than establishing a structure for the development of science and technology in Australia into the future. It is also serious because it is confusing. I am not one given to personal explanations, but I noticed the ubiquitous Mr McGauran on television the other day explaining that I had told CSIRO that it was not allowed to sack anybody for a fortnight. I do not know where on earth he got that from. I will not bother to make a personal explanation about that sort of thing. He has an appalling ignorance of his shadow portfolio. For example, he claims that there has been a 28 per cent cut in the CSIRO's appropriation over the past five years. In fact, it was 17 per cent. He talks about a $40m shortfall in the CSIRO budget, which suggests that he gets all of his information from the Australian newspaper because that was a typographical error in the Australian. It said $40m when it meant $14m. For a responsible shadow Minister to say in a press release that that was the shortfall for CSIRO is extraordinary.

He also takes the convenient figure of $20m off the top of his head and claims that is what is needed for infrastructure redevelopment, without presenting any evidence for this claim. He states in his press release that we provided an average of $18m a year for CSIRO, but ignores the substantial funds which will flow from external earnings and through flow-ons from industry taking advantage of the tax incentive. It is very difficult to work out which Opposition spokesman is correct about all of this-or less wrong. It is clear that the former, Mr Beale, cannot read and the second, Mr McGauran, cannot count. Their future as shadow Ministers must surely be in doubt and Mr Peacock, as a new leader enjoying a second honeymoon, has an opportunity on the basis of these sorts of press statements to do something about the Opposition's front bench.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that under a proposed plan for the telecommunications equipment industry companies will be expected to meet points targets for local content, research and development and exports before any of their equipment will be authorised for connection to the network by Austel, the Australian Telecommunications Authority? Does not this points target plan conflict with the approach of the Government's partnership for development program, as it may lead to biased resource allocation between computer and telecommunications uses? If so, does this mean that the Government is finally abandoning the notion of corporate citizenship by embracing a points target plan for telecommunications equipment? Will not the Government's information industries strategy also be compromised by the fragmentation of the development of the industry and the diminishing of the importance of linkages between local and international firms?

—Senator Lewis's question requires a very detailed answer and I am not in a position to give that at the moment. Certainly I am aware of a proposal for the telecommunications equipment industry which has targets in respect of exports, research and development and local content. Senator Lewis did not mention that the proposal is of interim duration only; it is not intended to last forever. It has a sunset provision in it. The local content requirements are adjusted downwards, I recall, over the period. It is a transitional arrangement, not a fixed one. That makes a lot of difference to what I see as the burden of Senator Lewis's concern. Senator Lewis asked whether the plan is in conflict with the partnership for development program for the information industries generally. The answer to that question is no. I recall taking a considerable amount of time to ensure that there was no conflict between the two. I will obtain a more detailed answer to the other aspects of the question and provide it as soon as possible.
—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and relates to the Antarctic.
—Are you sending him down there next week?
—I have no difficulty in accepting the new found credentials of Opposition members in caring about conservation issues, having watched them recycle all their old rubbish yesterday.
—We will have to knock you into shape.

—On my worst day I am in better shape than Senator Alston. Does the Minister recall concerns expressed in the Senate and in the press in February last year regarding experiments on animals in the Antarctic using radioactive isotopes and anaesthesia? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of the inquiry that he initiated in response to these concerns? What action has been taken to ensure that experiments involving animals are justifiable and are carried out in a humane manner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the publicity associated with the animal experiments in the Antarctic last year. They particularly concerned the use of radioactive isotopes and anaesthetic on penguins. As a result of the concern honourable senators may recall that I suspended those research programs and instituted an inquiry into the animal research program in the Antarctic with particular reference to animal welfare considerations. The report examined the use of radioactive substances in experiments with animals, the use of anaesthetics in surgical procedures on animals, and possible alternative techniques to achieve the same objectives. A specialist group from within the Antarctic Science Advisory Committee was set up to examine the matter. The Chairman was Professor Gilmour, the Professor of Environmental Studies at Macquarie University. In general, the group commented very favourably upon the research programs of our Antarctic research expeditions. It stated:

ANSWER.PARA: The techniques used in current Antarctic research projects involving live animals are justified on conservation grounds and these techniques are being administered humanely. Australian Antarctic scientists are amongst the leaders in the development of the use of humane methods for collecting scientific data on Antarctic animals as an alternative to killing the animals which has been, and still is, a common practice in the research programs of some other nations.

The working group pointed out, however, that there could be some improvements in the administrative procedures which were being used in that research program and in the handling of radioactive materials in particular. The report made a number of key recommendations. I accepted one of them, which was that the program which had been suspended should be resumed. I agreed with that. In addition, the working group recommended that there ought to be an animal care and ethics committee on a permanent basis and that a code of practice should be developed to cover our research involving Antarctic animals.

The full title of the committee which has now been set up is the Antarctic Animal Care and Ionising Radiation Usage Ethics Committee. The Committee will report to the Director of the Antarctic Division and will receive all the necessary support from that Division to carry out its activities. The Committee's approval will be required in the future for any research programs which are to be undertaken in the Antarctic. More importantly, it will also be responsible for making sure that those programs are monitored. The membership of the Committee and its terms of reference are based on National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines for animal ethics committees. That code of practice is currently being developed and I think it will be announced shortly. It will mean that our proposed experiments are properly examined and monitored and it should give some reassurance to those who have been concerned about whether our activities involving Antarctic animals have been humane.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS: SICK LEAVE CERTIFICATES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of reports in today's press which highlight the incidence of sick leave being taken by air traffic controllers? Is the Minister aware that the Civil Aviation Authority has now requested a sickness certificate for each and every occasion on which any sick leave is sought by air traffic controllers? Will the Minister advise the chamber of any steps the Civil Aviation Authority will be taking to deal with air traffic controllers who do not produce sickness certificates and, indeed, who persist in taking uncertificated sick leave? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Civil Aviation Authority is acting responsibly in its dealings with the air traffic controllers union-the Civil Air Operations Officers Association of Australia-before Sydney Airport or, indeed, other airports around Australia are closed indefinitely due to disputation within the industry?
—I have seen the press article to which the honourable senator refers, but I do not seem to have a brief on the issue. This question deserves a proper answer, which I will give him as soon as I can.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Australian Medical Association (AMA) alleges that the proposed system of accreditation of medical practitioners for Medicare purposes will discriminate against part time practitioners, the majority of whom are women combining careers and motherhood. Has consideration been given to this aspect of accreditation, and can the Minister allay the anxiety which the AMA's allegations have engendered?

—Yes, I think I can allay the anxieties which the Australian Medical Association's allegations have engendered, as Senator Giles puts it. The new package which has been announced makes no distinction between male and female doctors. There have been concerns about the effects these arrangements will have on part time general practitioners, who it is recognised will be predominantly women. The new arrangements are designed specifically to provide incentives for doctors to undertake vocational training appropriate to general practice, to participate in continuing medical education and quality assurance programs and to provide comprehensive primary medical care to all patients. Part time general practitioners who work at least two sessions a week in the same general practice will be considered by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to be in general practice for the purpose of enrolment. For those doctors who do not enrol, existing time-tiered fees will continue so that no patient or doctor will be disadvantaged.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY AND SEX DISCRIMINATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his now not-so-new-found capacity as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. How does he reconcile his proud protestations about his Government's record on equal employment opportunity (EEO) and sex discrimination with the plight of Ms Helen Styles, a journalist with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the landmark Federal Court decision with respect to her allegations? Is the Minister aware that Ms Styles successfully claimed in the Federal Court that the Department had discriminated against her, and that the Government is now appealing against that finding? If so, will he tell us why it is doing so? How can he justify the situation that Ms Styles was unable to use EEO as a shield against unfair employment practices because of the Department's failure to properly and promptly implement an EEO program? Why has the Government paid so little attention to implementing equal employment opportunity programs in its own backyard? Are not the decision to appeal against the finding and, indeed, the failure to properly implement EEO in this Department, and probably others, simply an example of the Government not wanting to practise what it preaches?
—That was a neat little speech from the honourable senator, which I cannot match for rhetoric because I do not know enough about the facts.
—That is twice you have been caught out today. Get prepared.
—If I am to be caught out a third time, it will not be by Senator Boswell. I will obtain as soon as I can an answer in relation to Ms Styles's case and the suggestion of an appeal.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the forest and forest industry package just released by the Tasmanian Government in which that Government is committed to spending more than $50m? Can the Minister inform me how much of that package--
—This is the fifth question on Tasmania today.
—What would you know about forest practices in Tasmania?
—Order!

—I know that all the Opposition frontbenchers are very jumpy because the axe is about to fall. Can the Minister inform me how much of that package is the result of funds allocated to the Federal-State forest industry program to which both Federal and Tasmanian governments agreed following the Helsham decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Gray Government announced its forest and forest industry package as if there were a fresh initiative for the Tasmanian election, I had a sense of deja vu because the content of the package has a striking, if not absolutely exact, similarity to what the Commonwealth of Australia negotiated with Tasmania in the settlement of the aftermath of the Helsham report. Indeed, the components of the package that are now being paraded as if they are new and exciting were, in some part, proposals put by us, the Commonwealth, and in negotiations resisted by the State of Tasmania. Nonetheless, they are being brushed off and presented as if they are new initiatives and entirely the invention of the Liberal Party in Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of the other elements of the proposal released in Mr Gray's policy speech are those about which negotiations are to be held between the State of Tasmania and the Commonwealth. Negotiations about those elements have not yet started; nor has there been any initiative by the State of Tasmania to commence them. Yet the proposals in this policy document are presented as if those negotiations have been held, completed and settled. Indeed, the amounts of money in the Gray package are amounts that would be funded from the Commonwealth under the terms of settlement--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.
—Thank you, Mr President. I did not think any of the interjections were interfering with the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: The three elements of the package that I identify as ones to be settled are: how the plantation program is to be developed and organised, and what the management for intensive forestry will be; how the saw logs and veneer package, worth $7m, is to be allocated to improving the value added sector; and how the education, training and skills package, valued at $5m, is to be organised or arranged.

I find this recycling of what is an old agreement somewhat surprising in the wake of the announcement by Mr Gray to go to an election. On the other hand, when I look at what the soon to be elected Premier of Tasmania, Michael Field, had to say on the fine furniture design and skills package, I find a set of fresh initiatives which are quite engaging and quite exciting, and the sort of thing that workers in forests or forest-based industries in Tasmania would want to support. The three things which form the basis of his package are: a furniture skills training centre in the Huon Valley; and expansion of the University of Tasmania's School of Art design in wood course; and marketing, business management and financial support to assist with the development of production facilities as the basis of a cogent and progressive policy for this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is the Minister aware of a report, which recently appeared on the front page of the Melbourne Age, disclosing that Mr Justice Vincent of the Victorian Supreme Court had been approached for the position of Chairman of the National Crime Authority, but had subsequently declined the offer? As this information could only have come from the Minister or the Minister's office, will the Minister give the Senate an unequivocal assurance that he had no knowledge or awareness of this unauthorised disclosure? Notwithstanding this appalling breach of security, is the Minister aware of a later report in the Age indicating that a further incredibly inept approach was recently made to a Mr Peter Faris, QC, who believed that he was being offered the top job whereas, apparently, he was only being sounded out to be a member of the Authority? Is the end result that, with less than two months to go before the expiration of the term of the Chairman, not only does the Government have no successor in prospect, but one member has already announced his intention to retire and the other remaining member has threatened to retire unless offered the chairmanship? Finally, can the Minister explain the origin of the flood of damaging information which has led to the present fiasco and, in particular, can he tell the Senate why the Government is so opposed to the appointment as Chairman of Mr Peter Clark, a very capable and effective member of the Authority who is strongly supported by Mr Justice Stewart?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness I was asked this question! The basic underlying theme of the question was that an inept approach has been made to certain persons in relation to their serving as members of the National Crime Authority, an authority which is absolutely crucial in the fight which is sanctioned by this Parliament against serious crime throughout Australia. It is vested with special coercive powers that are not available to other police forces throughout Australia. Therefore, its membership is extremely important. For that reason, in January or February the Attorney-General wrote to the other Attorneys and police Ministers around Australia seeking their thoughts about and nominees for the positions that fall vacant on 30 June this year.

ANSWER.PARA: Rather than accept-which, of course, I do not-that the supposed leak concerning Mr Justice Vincent was somehow engineered by either my office, which it certainly was not, or the Attorney's office-I am quite confident it was not-I inform the Senate that the speculation which has attended the membership of the National Crime Authority has probably done some damage to the morale of those involved in the work of the Authority, and that is extremely unfortunate. I wish that that had not occurred. The approach to Mr Peter Faris, QC, rather than being inept, has resulted today in his acceptance of the position of Chairman of the National Crime Authority. Indeed, I am delighted that Mr Peter Faris has accepted the position which has been offered to him. Mr Faris is a leading member of the Victorian Bar, specialising in criminal law, and has acted as prosecutor in many major State and Federal prosecutions over the past five years. This work has included cases initiated by the National Crime Authority.

Mr Faris was admitted as a barrister and solicitor of the Victorian Supreme Court in 1963. He went to the Bar in 1970, was a founder of the Fitzroy Legal Service in 1972 and solicitor for the Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service from 1973-74. He returned to the Bar in 1975, taking silk in 1986. He is presently Chairman of the committee of review of Victorian drug laws-a committee of the Victorian Director of Public Prosecutions. It is evident that this appointment, which has been eagerly awaited both by the staff and personnel associated with the National Crime Authority and by all those associated with the fight against organised crime, marks a milestone as we now have a successor to Mr Justice Stewart, who has played a leading role in creating the situation under which the National Crime Authority has been at the forefront of the fight against organised crime. I hope that over the next week or so, with the consultations that take place with other agencies and organisations, the membership of the National Crime Authority will be completed well in time for the handover on 30 June.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I welcome the Government's belated announcement that the job has finally been filled after being hawked around for some months. The thrust of my question, which the Minister has not responded to, is whether Mr Faris, as reported in the Melbourne Age, was offered the job simply of a member but thought he was being offered the top job. Is that a fact or not? If it is not, why did the Minister not correct it when it appeared in the Age several weeks ago?
—Mr Faris has been offered the top job and he has accepted it.

—Is the Minister for Justice aware of the case of Mr Peter Vel of Sydney who was dismissed from the Department of Defence in May 1985 and is now on a hunger strike? Is it the case that Mr Vel was accepted as a client by the Australian Legal Aid Office (ALAO) in May 1985 in the matter of his dismissal, which he believed to be unfair, and his appeal was subsequently halted by Legal Aid in December 1986? Was Mr Vel's file given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on 24 July 1987 in order to review his claims, but was he not told until August 1988 that he was required to lodge a separate application concerning issues other than his dismissal from the Department of Defence? Was Mr Vel then informed that, as his application was not lodged within one year of his last contact with the Australian Legal Aid Office, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission could not act on his claim? Can the Minister explain these circumstances to the Senate and assure the Senate that everything which can now be done for Mr Vel is being done?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean made me aware of some of the elements of his question so I have somewhat prepared an answer. Firstly, I am aware that Mr Vel commenced his hunger strike on 24 April 1989. Secondly, the Commonwealth is not able to provide information in relation to Mr Vel's legal aid matters. These matters are completely within the control of the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission. If the honourable senator were to approach that Commission with Mr Vel's authority, it may be able to assist. Thirdly, Mr Vel's file relating to a race discrimination complaint against the Department of Defence was formally referred by the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on 13 April 1988. The Board had declined the matter as lacking in substance and Mr Vel had exercised his right to have the matter referred to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: In March 1988 Mr Vel first raised an issue regarding the ALAO and on 10 August 1988 lodged a written request to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that these complaints be joined. On 11 August 1988 the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission advised that that joinder was not possible as the complaint against ALAO related to issues other than those arising under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, but that the Commission would carefully examine any other possible action within its jurisdiction. After careful consideration the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission advised Mr Vel in March 1989 that his complaint against the ALAO was outside its jurisdiction on a number of grounds.

Fourthly, Mr Vel's case against the Department of Defence has been set down for hearing before the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on 19 May 1989. I have been assured by that Commission that everything that can reasonably be expected to be done for Mr Vel has been done and will continue to be done. As the Commission is an independent statutory authority charged with responsibility for making decisions under the enactments it administers, it is not appropriate for the Attorney-General to intervene in Mr Vel's case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to his confusing and inconsistent answer to my question yesterday in relation to a Bill to control prices in Victoria. Did the Minister refer to the coordination of direction of pricing policy and say that it was the Federal Government's aim to achieve further intervention in particular States? Will the Minister deny that this is evidence of the Federal Government's hidden agenda to apply a system of national price control through coordination of State governments?
—I suppose we should take note of the fact that after months of hibernation Senator Messner, in the last two days, has asked two questions and we should welcome that.
—He is about to go back to sleep, though.

—Probably in more comfortable circumstances. There is no hidden or overt Federal Government agenda to impose price control on a national level. The honourable senator knows that; he just seems to be fluttering up some furore before he goes.

—I ask a supplementary question: How can the Minister explain that he is coordinating a policy of intervention by the various States in pricing control? He has indicated that the policy is for the Federal Government to coordinate that.

—If Senator Messner had taken his position seriously over recent years he would have recognised that in March 1987 the Prime Minister announced at the inaugural Ruby Hutchison Memorial Address that we would be setting up a consultative committee of Commonwealth and State pricing officials to look at initiatives aimed at securing maximum price restraint. That is as far as the Federal Government's intervention in this area goes.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to claims made by the Queensland coal industry that Queensland rail freight charges on coal are restricting exports and the development of new mines? Are these claims correct? If so, what is the extent of restriction on exports and development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have noticed the claims by the Queensland coal industry. They are well based in fact. I also noticed that, perhaps as a desperate last move, before the by-election in Queensland at the weekend, the Premier of Queensland has made an offer to reduce the freight rates although that offer has been received with a great deal of suspicion by the coal industry in Queensland, and rightly, because of the huge impost-the hidden taxation-on the coal industry by virtue of the freight rates. The industry's performance has slipped considerably in 1986-87. Coal production was down by 4 per cent in Queensland in 1986 and employment fell by 867 or 8 per cent in Queensland because of that. The industry faces a more optimistic future because of a tightening of the world market, but is still in a very highly competitive international environment and the freight rates are one of the biggest single costs on the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Brian Galligan, a political scientist from the Australian National University, in a paper entitled Queensland Railways and Export Coal published in the Australian Journal of Public Administration in March 1987 estimated that the rail freight surcharge for Queensland coal in 1985-86 was $354m. Using the same type of analysis that Dr Galligan has used, the Queensland rail freight surcharge in 1986-87 would have risen to a massive $399m in 1987 and $376m in 1988.

Queensland freight rates are a hidden tax and they are used by the Queensland Government to subsidise other activities. Because they are a hidden tax, there is no scrutiny of them. We do not know accurately how much tax has been imposed. Therefore, we do not know how the tax is reallocated, and this enables the Queensland Government to pretend that Queensland is a low taxing State when, in fact, it is not. The imposition of the freight rates masks the real level of taxation in Queensland. I think the most important point from an export point of view is that it is a tax on exports. This is a tax on the coal industry and it is a flat tax on volume of production in the form of freight transport. At a time in which the Australian coal industry is struggling to rationalise internally and compete in tight international markets, the Queensland Government is retarding the ability of the industry to do that by imposing this pernicious tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time on 2 May 1989, Senator McLean gave me notice of a question relating to an award of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission relating to the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade. I inform Senator McLean, in relation to his question and a further question asked by Senator Sanders, that I am not yet able to provide detailed answers to those questions. The matters involved go back over a history of 15 years and they involve examination in detail of decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, interpretation of an award which was made in 1975, a determination of the extent of authority of the Fire Commissioner and a number of other matters. They are complex for many reasons and I assure the honourable senators that the answer is in the course of preparation and will be made available as soon as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 August last year, Senator Chaney asked a supplementary question about whether the Government would explore the possibility of international action over the massacre in Burundi, `in light of the endless attention given to South Africa'.
—Seven months ago, was it?
—Nearly nine months ago.
—A thoughtful Government.

—When the question was asked I treated it as something of a rhetorical flourish and not really justifying a response as a question, but since I have been harangued periodically by Mr Spender, the shadow foreign Minister, for not answering the question, and because he has been having such a rough time lately, being in the wrong country for the wrong election and putting the wrong date on his letter, as the Sydney Morning Herald said this morning, and since it is his last full day as shadow Minister, I thought that it would be a nice parting gesture to give him the answer that he has apparently long been craving. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard. It is about double standards between Burundi and South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

There has been international action in response to the massacre in Burundi. In August 1988, at the request of the 40th Session of the UN Commission on Human Rights' Sub-Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities, the UN Secretary General sent a message to the President of Burundi expressing concern about the massacre in Burundi and indicating the readiness of the UN to provide assistance, particularly in respect of displaced persons. The Government would of course support the provision of UN assistance to the victims of the violence in Burundi.
The UN High Commissioner for Refugees has provided relief from his Emergency Reserve Fund to assist those affected by the appalling events.

During the 45th session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, which concluded on 10 March 1989, efforts were made to introduce a draft resolution concerning the massacre in Burundi. The draft did not come to a vote, however, principally because of strong opposition by some African members.

I reject the implicit suggestion that the human rights situations in Burundi and South Africa require precisely similar responses from Australia. In South Africa, the policy of Apartheid and the violence used to support it are systematic and institutionalised. Australia's response is intended to place pressure on the South African Government to change longstanding policies. The situation in Burundi, by contrast, was characterised by a relatively short-term outburst of inter-communal violence which subsided quickly. It is difficult to see what constructive and effective intervention the international community could have made at that time, beyond condemning the abuse of human rights and calling on all those involved to refrain from further violence. This is precisely what Australia and a number of other countries have done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during Question Time Senator Hill asked Senator Bolkus, as the Minister representing me in my absence, about the missing yacht Patanela and what the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and other Federal authorities were doing about it. I am aware of concerns regarding attempts by State and Commonwealth authorities to locate the yacht Patanela and its crew. I can only comment on Commonwealth actions in this case.

ANSWER.PARA: In November 1988 the yacht Patanela was reported missing off the coast of New South Wales. I am informed that the sea safety branch of the Department of Transport and Communications notified Interpol in November 1988 indicating that relevant authorities in Papua New Guinea, Fiji and New Caledonia had been informed that the yacht was missing. The AFP was subsequently informed that the yacht was missing. Of course, the AFP has neither the jurisdiction nor a capacity to mount searches for missing vessels. Its responsibility in such cases is to determine whether there has been a breach of Commonwealth law. In that regard the AFP has undertaken extensive inquiries throughout Australia and overseas in an effort to establish the vessel's movements and in particular to determine whether the vessel is still afloat and its crew alive. Those inquiries are continuing, but the AFP advises that in the circumstances it is concerned for the welfare of the crew.

In addition the Interpol Secretariat has advised all member nations of the disappearance of the vessel and requested that they maintain a watch for it. Full descriptions and photographs of the vessel have been forwarded as part of this request. I have been in contact with one of Senator Hill's House of Representatives colleagues-I cannot recall his name at the moment-who has also been in correspondence with me on this issue. Perhaps I could make that file of correspondence available to Senator Hill.

DEBATE.TITLE: WOODCHIPPING INDUSTRY, SOUTH-EASTERN NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Dunn proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the government to reassess its powers in relation to the woodchipping industry of southeastern New South Wales in view of the widespread public opposition to the destruction of a fast diminishing area of mature forest in the region, and, in particular, the need for the government to exercise its responsibilities to protect the Australian environment under the Heritage Act and under the terms of the Harris Daishowa woodchipping licence, and to take into account the:
(a) findings by scientists who have conducted studies on the effect of woodchipping on the wildlife (plants and animals) of the forests;
(b) the breaches by Harris Daishowa of its woodchip licence agreement;
(c) the development of alternative timber industries, particularly hardwood plantations and value-added timber products.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I use the only opportunity that I will be given during this term of parliament to raise a matter of public importance to raise a matter that I believe to be of great public importance to many thousands of Australians, not just those who live in the south-east forests. While I understand that matters of great import have been announced within the last couple of days, I believe that the question of the future use of this country's resources is in the long run a much more momentous decision than who sits in which deck chair on the Titanic as it sinks.

SPEECH.PARA: I am raising this matter today as I know that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) is on the verge of making a decision that will determine not only the fate of the forests in the Eden woodchip concession area of south-eastern New South Wales, but also will set the tone for the future use of the resources in this country. In particular, this will be a guage of the Government's commitment to sustainable forest industry, one in which jobs, as well as the environment, may be preserved in the long term for the future benefit of all Australians, and not just sectional interests in the population.

It is my belief that the Government, and in particular Senator Cook, needs to exercise imagination in the solution of what has been a very vexatious problem in the Eden region, one which has divided the community unnecessarily. This division could be held almost instantaneously by a wise decision by the Government which would and could satisfy the apparently conflicting demands in the local community. Nearly 500 people, including myself, have been prepared to be arrested over this issue. Threats have been made against individuals living in the area and some have taken out their frustrations on the wildlife. It was with great distress that I recently learned that five koalas had been shot in the Tantawangalo area some years ago. If the Government does not make the right decision, this divisiveness will continue and nobody will be satisfied. The forests could be lost; the wildlife would disappear; the jobs would decline with the diminishing resources; and the beautiful old-growth trees would be lost as a source of mental and spiritual rejuvenation.

It is my contention that in the face of the extraordinary obduracy by the New South Wales Government, particularly by the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources, Ian Causley, in failing to provide the vital information that Senator Cook needs, the Federal Government must take a leading role in the resolution of the problem and exercise the powers it has under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act and in the drafting of the conditions for the woodchip licence. Section 30 (1) of the Heritage Act reads:

Each Minister shall give all such directions and do all such things as, consistently with any relevant laws, can be given or done by him for ensuring that the Department administered by him or any authority of the Commonwealth in respect of which he has ministerial responsibilities does not take any action that adversely affects, as part of the National Estate, a place that is in the Register unless he is satisfied that there is no feasible and prudent alternative to the taking of that action and that all measures that can reasonably be taken to minimise the adverse effect will be taken and shall not himself take any such action unless he is so satisfied.

Yesterday I asked Senator Cook whether he had sought the information necessary to make a judgment on such feasible and prudent alternatives to logging in the National Estate. His reply suggested that he had sought the information but had not yet received it. He said:

Have I requested information from my Department on the Forestry Commission of NSW? Yes, I have. Am I aware of my statutory obligation to find prudent and feasible alternatives? Yes, I am. The reason why I have requested that information is to be properly informed to make a responsible judgment on prudent and feasible alternatives so that when I have my next meeting with the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources, Ian Causley, I am able to have the informational base to assert the consideration of prudent and feasible alternatives that I will make.

I do not believe Senator Cook has yet met with Mr Causley, nor yet received the information he requires. He has been waiting months for this information from the New South Wales Forestry Commission and the Minister. That he has not yet received it can only mean that the Forestry Commission of New South Wales, perhaps because it has something to hide, is being uncooperative or that it is keeping poor records.

Much of the debate about the value of the south-east forests centres on their conservation value. I suppose Senator Cook and others know that I have been involved as an editor for a very long time in a long term series of studies conducted by Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service officer, Dan Lunney. Mr Lunney was directed by the New South Wales Cabinet in 1979 to research the effects of woodchipping on the wildlife of the region. He has produced some 20 papers in which he conclusively demonstrates the deleterious impact of woodchipping on the native fauna of the region. I will read into the record some of the conclusions of his many studies. In a paper entitled `Kangaroos, wallabies and rat kangaroos: their past, present and future in the woodchip agreement area of the Eden region, south-east New South Wales', Daniel Lunney states:

. . . there is a strong case to suggest that the current areas set aside, or designated to be set aside from woodchipping, are inadequate for the long-term survival of all macropodid and potoroid populations in the Woodchip Agreement Area, particularly away from the coast, and that a major revision of both land-use and land management options is warranted.

In another study Dan Lunney and Tanya Leary have produced, `The impact on native mammals of land use changes and exotic species in the Bega district, New South Wales, since settlement', published in the Australian Journal of Ecology last year, it is stated:

If the remaining forest habitats are cleared or intensively logged or managed without detailed knowledge of the resident wildlife, it can be concluded from historical records that further extinctions will be inevitable, particularly of those species that have now become uncommon or rare in the district and are known to be dependent upon the remaining mature forest habitat . . .

In this context, the current plan (Forestry Commission of NSW 1982) to log a substantial proportion of the State Forests for woodchips and sawlogs by the year 2010 will undoubtedly continue the deleterious impact of the European invasion.
In another study, `Roost selection by Gould's long-eared bat . . . in logged forest on the south coast of New South Wales', by Daniel Lunney and others, the conclusion is:

The second logging cycle, due before the turn of the century, will remove most of the remaining suitable roost trees before they have been replaced in the coupes logged in the first cycle. Therefore we conclude that the second logging cycle, under the current logging plan (Forestry Commission of NSW 1982), will have a major deleterious impact on the survival of N. gouldi unless gullies are redefined to include all drainage lines and that these remain unlogged. An additional strategy, to maintain a range of larger tree sizes, is to extend to more than a century the time over which the second logging cycle takes place.
In the Jurasius hearing in March of last year, Mr Justice Hemmings concluded:
I am satisfied that as a consequence of the nature of the activity-
that is, woodchipping-

it is likely that many species of fauna will be adversely affected by the current logging operations and this effect is likely to be compounded by fire. I am also satisfied that if the current logging operations continue for a long term it is likely that arboreal populations could significantly change, particularly if regrowth forests fail to provide adequate habitats for birds and mammals.

Whilst it is apparent that tree dwelling birds and mammals are not evenly distributed in the region, I am satisfied that existing management procedures and prescriptions do not guarantee the maintenance of composition and description.

There are other papers, but I am running out of time. These other papers suggest that the present system of parks and reserves is inadequate for conserving the full range of ecosystems in the region. An earlier paper I quoted from supported exactly that point.

The National Estate areas have been recognised as being of particular value. I know that Dr Harry Recher, who was a co-author with me on an ecology book published some 10 years ago and which won a prize from the Royal Australian Zoological Society, has worked closely with the Forestry Commission. In a 1987 study, he recommended certain new prescriptions for dealing with wildlife management in the region. One of his findings was that large, specially selected patches of unlogged mature forest should be left in the compartments of the logging areas now and until the regeneration on adjacent logged areas is mature in 100 to 150 years from now. Dr Recher is very critical of the Forestry Commission and says that it has refused to take up those recommendations. Last month, he said:

I've attempted to cooperate with the Forestry Commission and Harris Daishowa to develop wildlife management policies in the context of a continuing woodchip industry, but they no longer appear willing to implement such policies . . .
In view of this, the only way the conservation of wildlife can now be assured in the region is by the creation of new national parks immediately.

It is excellent that the Government has recognised the value of the National Estate areas and has put Tantawangalo and Coolangubra on the list. We know that under section 6 (c) of Coolangubra's export licence condition Daishowa is not supposed to take pulpwood for export from these areas, yet the District Forester, Tony Howe, admitted on local radio that the company was extracting pulpwood from Coolangubra. In a remarkable display of casuistry-a word that I find myself having to use more frequently than I care to in this place-Senator Cook denied that the wood had been extracted for export. He said it had been quarantined, whereas I maintained it had been stockpiled. He wrote to Rick Humphries of the Australian Conservation Foundation as follows:
. . . this material from Coolangubra is quarantined and may not be ever approved for export.

Whatever word is used, the effect is exactly the same. Daishowa had cut the wood from a National Estate area and was leaving it on the ground in the hope of getting permission to export it. If that permission could not be obtained, the wood was going to be burned or left to rot away and be good for nothing. At least two lawyers disagreed with Senator Cook in relation to this matter. Mr A. Robertson, of Wentworth Chambers, last month wrote:

. . . it is no answer to say that no approval has yet been given for export of pulp wood already extracted. It does not appear that a further approval is necessary. Any approval must be given beforehand to avoid a failure to comply with the condition or restriction.
At the end Mr Robertson says:

In summary, in my opinion, on the basis of my instructions the company may not have complied with the condition or restriction to which it was subject by virtue of regulation 9 and clause 6 (c) of the schedule. My reason for this conclusion is that the condition or restriction is directed to the operation of extracting pulp wood for export as woodchips and the Department did not, before that extraction took place, notify the company in writing that the proposed operations were acceptable to it.

There is another decision supporting that of Mr Robertson, by Nicholas Seddon from the Faculty of Law at the Australian National University. I ask Senator Cook whether this means that Daishowa could cut out the entire forests of the National Estate areas and leave the timber on the ground in expectation of permission to export, and whether he could or would do nothing about it. That is the logical extension of his argument. If that is the case, section 6 (c) is nothing but a paper tiger.

TALK.START.PARA: —A paper tiger made out of timber.

—Good point. Senator Cook is very proud of section 6 (c), which, he says, he inserted in the export licence to give him a belt-and-braces control over cutting in the National Estate areas. Well, I am afraid that the belt and braces are slack and the senator's pants are in danger of falling down.

SPEECH.PARA: Daishowa has committed other breaches of its licence conditions. It is clear that wood suitable for saw logs is being taken to the chip mill for pulp wood-I saw this for myself when I was there-and there have been serious-and, I believe, credible-allegations that the company is taking wood from unauthorised areas. Yesterday, when I asked Senator Cook about these matters, he avoided answering me directly, so I ask him again today: is he prepared to request records of tonnages going over the weighbridge into the chip mill?

The third matter that I want to address is a question on which timber workers and conservationists are in 100 per cent agreement-that is, the necessity of establishing a sustainable resource that is managed both for its conservation values and for long-term employment. But let us put this in an economic context and look at the contribution that Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd-or should I just say Daishowa?-has made to Australia since it started in the early 1970s. Firstly, it is a wholly Japanese owned company. The Federal and State governments at the time allowed this on condition that Australian equity would be sought in the future. That did not happen, so our largest woodchip export scheme, and one of our most significant forest industries, remains 100 per cent foreign-owned.

Secondly, in the first eight years of operation the company declared its profits and paid no tax, but at the same time its parent company rose to third position among Japan's huge paper manufacturers and made after-tax profits of $26m in that same period. This meant that the Australian subsidiary was selling its woodchips to the parent company-that is, to itself-for the costs of production. As a result, Australia missed out on taxes for those earnings, and Daishowa still has little incentive to increase its prices and, hence, pay additional taxes to Australia when it is selling chips to itself.

Thirdly, Australia receives the lowest price per tonne for its woodchips of all the major exporters to Japan, despite the fact that our chips are of the highest quality and are the most uniform. Why the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, does not set better prices is a mystery. Some cynics say that our forests are thrown in to support continuing coal exports from New South Wales. Senators may not know that Daishowa has also received considerable funding from State and Federal governments over the years. It received at least $600,000 in export expansion grants from the Fraser Government. A reduction of $400,000 was made by the New South Wales Government in the company's royalty payment to help it to build a road to the mill, and the company also received a $125,000 grant from the New South Wales Government to help in the housing of company employees.

Overall, the royalties paid by Daishowa have been low. Last year they amounted to about $12m, with about $60m in annual export revenue-a drop in the bucket compared to a wood product trade deficit of about $1.5 billion. This is a very small amount when we consider that we have given over nearly 300,000 hectares of State forest to the industry. Our woodchips are then manufactured in Japan and sold back to us at vastly inflated prices. The industry now directly employs about 136 people, with 1,500 dependants, but it is the least labour-intensive of the forest industries. As woodchipping replaces sawmilling, the employment opportunities diminish. Employment in Australian forest industries fell by 25 per cent, or 26,000 jobs, between 1970 and 1985 and can be expected to continue falling.
Nobody likes to see our old native-growth forests being sold off for a song, and everybody would like to see the development of a sustainable industry-even Senator Cook, who said last year;
. . . woodchipping is the lowest value, lowest effort way to export forest products. Relying on exports of woodchips sells short the resources on which our children depend.
At a recent rally in Canberra, Senator McMullan said:
I believe it is important that this country move to a situation where we are able to sustain a level of forestry operations which does not further denude our remaining native forests.
Logging operations in Australia should not be carried out in our priceless natural forests. Forestry operations should move to plantations on previously cleared land.
Clearly, people in the Federal Government oppose the current operations at Eden.

The Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) and other conservation groups have put forward detailed proposals for the development of labour-intensive hardwood plantations across the country. The ACF publication The Wood and the Trees argues for the establishment of between 250,000 and 405,000 hectares of eucalypt plantations over the next 15 to 30 years, to be introduced at the rate of about 10,000 hectares per year. It is clear that what is required is a rapid transition of the industry to a plantation-based industry, improved resource utilisation, and a greater commitment to value-added processing of extracted timber, yet in the 20 years since the establishment of Daishowa no feasibility studies have been carried out. These are essential in evaluating the full range of policy options pertaining to the conservation of the region's native forests and the development of an ecologically sustainable and economically viable forest industry.

I urge Senator Cook to give the matters that I have raised the most serious consideration before he makes his final decision. I urge him to give the same consideration to Senator Richardson's recommendations. Two hundred thousand people have put their names on a petition; 9,000 have written to Bob Hawke; 500 have been arrested. Clearly this is a major election issue. I should like to see a wise decision on the part of the Federal Government and on the part of Senator Cook. I remind him that former Premier Neville Wran regarded the conservation of the New South Wales rainforests as one of his Government's greatest achievements. Let us hope that one of the Federal Government's greatest achievements will be the conservation and the sound economic and sustainable management of the south-east forests of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I want to thank Senator Dunn for introducing this matter for debate. Not often enough do we debate matters of real import to the community. This is an opportunity to debate one of them, and I acknowledge the honourable senator's effort in bringing it forward for that purpose. It would have been better had the debate been arranged for the next meeting week of the Senate. That would have enabled me, as I said yesterday, to hold a meeting with the Minister for Natural Resources in New South Wales, Ian Causley, and to put to him the Commonwealth Government's positive proposition on how the woodchipping licence should be written so as to protect the areas of great environmental sensitivity in the south-east forests. Then the debate could have been about the substance of what the Commonwealth would do and was proposing to do, rather than about what it may do. Much of this debate is jumping at shadows over what may happen. We could have had a better informed debate if we had been dealing with what was proposed. However, I acknowledge the purpose of the debate and I thank Senator Dunn for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I also acknowledge that Senator Dunn has deep convictions on this subject. I respect and acknowledge her convictions. In what I am about to say I will not be attacking those convictions, but I do disagree with her argument in support of them. Before going to the text of what I want to say, let me correct a couple of comments that the honourable senator made as to fact. First, there was the question of whether or not Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd sells to itself in Japan at a price below the market price. If it did it would be engaging in transfer pricing and committing an offence under the tax Act. The prices at which Harris-Daishowa sells is part of the export approval process and must be approved by the Commonwealth Government before an export licence is granted. Those prices are considered against a basket of prices for woodchip sales from companies elsewhere in Australia to other companies in Japan where, to the extent that there is a market in woodchips, there is a free market. That free market level is regarded as a benchmark for the purposes of assessing those prices. Secondly, the price of woodchips obtained for the Australian product is compared with the price of woodchips from other sources around the world. I disagree with Senator Dunn that there is a transfer pricing component and that Australian woodchips sell for the lowest price in the world. As a matter of record and of fact, those comments are not true. Senator Dunn's matter of public importance today states:
The need for the government to reassess its powers in relation to the woodchipping industry of southeastern New South Wales . . .

It raises a question which is basic to this debate and to the way in which the public approach to this debate has been clouded. The question fundamentally is: What are the responsibilities and powers of the Commonwealth of Australia on this issue and what are the responsibilities and powers of the State of New South Wales? Let me go to the facts. We operate in this Parliament under the Federal Constitution. That Constitution was composed by the colonies before 1901. It consists of what work they did, what powers have been ceded by the States since, and what has been decided by the people of Australia in referenda and how it has been interpreted by the High Court of Australia. Under that Constitution and under the set of powers it confers on me as a Minister of State and on this Government, we do not have, as a government, the power to manage the forests in any of the States of Australia. Therefore we do not have and cannot take responsibility for the way in which those forests are managed. The constitutional responsibility for that rests with the States. Some people in this chamber may wish it to be otherwise. Honourable senators to some extent may well count me in on that. But that is the situation. It is with what exists that we must deal, not with what we would wish to exist.

Under the Constitution what powers do I have? The specific power that I have in this particular case is the power of approving export. In the process of approving export I have attached to export licences, as have my predecessors in office, conditions relating to where the materials that are to be exported are drawn from. That exercise of power by the Commonwealth has so far gone unchallenged. I say `unchallenged' because it has not been tested. If it were tested there might be a cloudy result; I do not know. I believe we have that power. On the basis of believing that we have that power, we have imposed conditions of that nature. It is about those conditions, how far the Commonwealth can impose them and what are reasonable conditions, that we are talking about when we talk about the Commonwealth's power.

That leads me to where the Opposition is fundamentally misdirected in relation to logging in the south-eastern forest. It is fundamentally misdirected because the State of New South Wales-which manages the New South Wales Forestry Commission, which manages the forests, which determines the sequence of cuts and which has set up the environmental impact statement to justify proceeding-has primary carriage. If there is opposition to what the State of New South Wales is proposing that is where the opposition should be directed, not to the Commonwealth.

I would feel more convinced about the argument that is put if in last year's New South Wales election campaign, when the Unsworth Government proposed the declaration of vast areas of the south-east forest as a national park, the effort that is now being put into lobbying the Commonwealth was put into returning the Unsworth Government and thus protecting the forests in the way in which the Unsworth Government at that time proposed. But the environmental movement, as a matter of record-this is a matter of great pity to it and one of great sorrow to me-chose to stand out of that election and not to support a Labor government with a positive program in that State. After doing that and getting the election result that it did-the return of a conservative government-it comes to the Labor Government in the Federal arena and says, `Now use your lesser powers, to fix up a situation which we didn't take political action to fix up when we could have in the New South Wales election'. That is a fundamental criticism that is justifiably made of the environmental movement and the way in which it has prosecuted its claims. I regret that this criticism has to be made; it is a matter of fact that it has to be made.

On the basis of that, let me recite where we are up to in this circumstance. On 29 December 1988, after tabling in the Senate the documents that led me to a conclusion and after tabling the principles upon which I based my decision, I issued a woodchip export licence for Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd subject to negotiation with the State of New South Wales on what areas of the forest should be properly protected. Since then I have had three negotiations with the State of New South Wales. I am as yet to arrive at a conclusion with it on an agreement between the Commonwealth and the State on the areas to be protected and on a number of other things touching on the timber industry in New South Wales. These include questions such as how to prevent logs that ought to go to sawmills going to a woodchipper and how to ensure that the maximum extraction is obtained from sawlogs and a minimum, therefore, of waste material is generated for woodchipping. Those negotiations, I expect, will conclude next week. Ian Causley and I are still trying to find in our itineraries next week a time when we can meet to have what I expect will be the last round of negotiations. They are certainly running well over time. I think that that is common ground among all those concerned with this debate that it is well over time that this matter was resolved. That is where we are up to.

What am I operating on? I am operating on a number of fundamental principles that this Government holds dear and on some statutory obligations that I am bound to observe. When I say bound to observe, I am happily bound to observe them, I might add. The first and most fundamental statutory obligation that is imposed on me in the issuance of this licence is to obtain advice on what the environmental consequences of the cutting would be. To obtain that information I have consulted my colleague Senator Richardson, who has advised me. In consultation with each other we have released publicly his advice to me so that it is a matter of public record so that what this Government does is out in the open and transparent and that can be judged on the judgments we make rather than on assumptions people may make about the evidentiary base upon which those judgments are made.

The advice from Senator Richardson was obtained because the direct statutory obligation is that under the Australian Heritage Commission Act I am required to find if cutting involves areas of national estate `prudent and feasible alternatives to cutting in the national estate'. I make the passing observation that the obligation to find prudent and feasible alternatives does not mean to say that there will never be any cutting in the National Estate. It means that if cutting is contemplated there has to be a sincere, conscientious and genuine effort by the Government to find alternatives before countenancing the possibility of cutting in the National Estate.

It is a matter of fact that cutting occurs in the National Estate in Australia. It is not a matter of fact that the National Estate is not cut. But when it is cut it is cut only after that exhaustive process and we are satisfied about prudent and feasible alternatives. It is cut in such a way as to preserve the environmental features of that area and in a way sensitive to the environmental concerns of that area. On the basis of that obligation I have taken-what is a fair cop for me-an undue amount of time in satisfying myself about that criterion. Fundamentally I have an obligation to discharge logically and reasonably that that criterion has been properly met. The proposal I intend to put to the New South Wales Government next week, if that is the time of the meeting, will, I believe, discharge that obligation properly. It will be open to public scrutiny. I will welcome criticism and comment on it. I believe it will be a sustainable position for the Government.

I have also said-and I repeat here-that there are other criteria too that guide me. I think there need to be other criteria. In this issue it is not simply a matter of looking at the environmental consequences. As Senator Dunn has said, we have a timber industry in Australia which is $1.5 billion in deficit. I think the recent figure is more horrendous; it is now $1.6 billion in deficit. That means that we import more timber than we export-an extra $1.6 billion net for forest products. That means that we in Australia acquiesce in the cutting of other nations' forests to feed our timber industry needs or we allow other nations to add value to the products such as woodchips we export. We buy back fine paper, for example-the highest commodity that can be obtained from the woodchip production cycle.

I find both those ideas objectionable. One of the purposes of my portfolio is to try to get to a position in which we do not cut down other people's forests. Some nations where we acquiesce in that cutting have environmental standards that I, frankly, find horrendous and which are less than those of Australia. I therefore think we ought to move to a degree of self-sufficiency in the timber industry. Another idea is that we should do the value adding in Australia. On the grounds that these things are essential, the criteria that I have publicly announced are criteria relating to the protection of the saw mill industry in the south-east; meeting the licence condition for Harris-Daishowa; and meeting environmental considerations. We cannot separate these criteria.

In the way in which this debate has been presented in this chamber we have heard an argument from the environmental side that was very well presented and necessary in the debate. But we need to hear the industry argument as well. There is a lack of sensitivity. Timber industry workers in Australia are among the lower paid workers, the most poorly educated workers. Because of the regional nature of their industry, they are located in geographically isolated pockets around the country. Some have invested their small savings into home ownership in those regions. If overnight we were to devastate that industry we would do a grievous disservice to people who ought not to bear the responsibility for structural reform in this country. As far as I am concerned, the party that I represent as a Minister exists to see that such people do not bear the burden of that structural reform. In that context I want to say that the basis of this Government's approach to how we manage the forest industry policy and deal with genuine, sincere and necessary environmental concerns is the key issue that ought to be considered. It is not simply a matter of arguing the purity of one position and ignoring the points that the other side has to put. They are essential and necessary points to be considered in arriving at a balanced outcome. I do not accuse Senator Dunn of that. She has tried to make the effort to meet the other side of the argument. But I do say that, in the public presentation of the argument and the way it comes across, there is a media conflict. It is one or the other. One must prevail at the cost of the other.

What this Government is concerned about is finding the right balance between both points of view so that that conflict is obviated. Our guiding star in that course is the national conservation strategy for Australia. We adopt that as the foundation of our approach. We also adopt the idea of environmentally safe development, using as our text the Brundtland Commission report Our Common Future. That is the approach that this Government uses. On that basis I have propounded the idea of a forests accord which recognises the aspirations of the industry, the environment and the legitimate aspirations of the wider Australian community. I believe the community also has a distinctly different aspiration in this.

On that basis I have argued strongly at the Australian Forestry Council, a meeting of all Australian Forest Ministers including the Commonwealth, and have obtained endorsement for a national plantation strategy for Australia. This industry does not need continuing conflict over environmentally sensitive matters. No-one in industry wants that. That point needs to be emphasised. What people want is security of resource. They want security of resource so that they can develop their industry, plan their investment and plan their industry growth. In my view, security of resource is obtained, particularly in the woodchipping industry-it is more difficult on the saw log side-through a plantation strategy which expands the resource base, dedicates resource to the needs of woodchip, pulp and paper manufactures and enables security of employment and the overcoming of anxieties for timber workers in Australia.

That notion is the centrepoint of the accord I have propounded. I am pleased to see that at least elements of the accord have now begun to catch on, in the public debate, as things that need to be endorsed.

This Government has also done a number of positive things, as recently as November, to try to obtain a logical and rational framework for carrying on this debate. In November last year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that we would set up a resource assessment commission. Legislation for that is before the other House right now. It will be before this chamber shortly. It is up to the resource assessment commission to make a balanced assessment of the conflicting needs of industry and the environment in an objective way in which the parties propounding particular points of view can come before it and be heard. That commission will be established to operate from 1 July. One of the first references will be the study of the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF). I acknowledge the very positive role of the ACF in its study The Wood and the Trees. I also acknowledge the industry plan for growth in Australia. The resolution of the competing views in those two studies will start to develop the framework.

Before my time runs out I should also mention the second major step. We are embarking on a national forest inventory which will include a study of old growth forest in Australia. The forest stock in this country will be calibrated so that we know what areas are key to an environmental perspective and what areas are key to an industry perspective. We have bolstered funding to the Heritage Commission and streamlined its procedures. We have done a number of things to encourage State governments to follow the Western Australian Government proposal of establishing a tree trust to generate investment in plantations both in the private sector and the public sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate commenced I thought I would be spending most of my time simply making reference to one or two of the specific details of Senator Dunn's motion such as those related to the question of the powers of the Commonwealth and its responsibilities under the Heritage Act. However, I find myself compelled instead to answer a number of points raised by Senator Cook in his presentation.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, Senator Cook raises the issue of what the Commonwealth's real powers are. He says in part that the Commonwealth cannot take responsibility for the way forests are managed. That is true in only the most narrow and limited sense. Certainly the Commonwealth does not have direct power or responsibility as the manager of the forests in New South Wales. However, at the end of the day, it is the Commonwealth's decision as to whether there can be export of woodchips or pulp-and, indeed, what terms and conditions should be imposed upon any such export licences. Senator Cook and the Commonwealth Government cannot get themselves away from the clear responsibility that they have to be satisfied that resources are managed in a way which they find sufficiently satisfactory to allow an export licence to be granted. The Fraser Government had no difficulty in addressing its mind to this matter over the question of sand mining on Fraser Island. It would have been just as easy for the Fraser Government to say, `Sandmining in Queensland is no responsibility of ours and therefore we do not accept any degree of responsibility.' We made it clear that an export licence on that occasion would not be granted and as a result of the clear exercise of Commonwealth power, environmental protection was extended over activities taking place within State jurisdiction, and there is nothing wrong with that and there is no reason for the Commonwealth to shirk that responsibility.

The second point that Senator Cook made to the environment movement is, `Don't come complaining to me. What you should have done was organise support for Barrie Unsworth'. What a pathetic argument that is. `If you wanted to come around and have any credibility with me,' says Senator Cook, `what you should have done was put the runs on the board for poor old Barrie'.
