TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Commission goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The concentration of market power among processors, manufacturers, distributors and retailers implied by these figures, indicates that powerful buyers have emerged in the acquisition of primary products. Similar concentration has developed in the supply of goods and services such as fertilisers and services provided by stock and station agents.
The Commission continues:

It is the Committee's view that countervailing power is necessary for economic efficiency in the rural industry. Without it, individual producers would be exposed to the power of large buyers which in some cases may be manifested in unfair business practices and insufficient market information.

In the present climate of deregulation the Committee believes that use of the authorisation procedure provided under the Trade Practices Act to sanction certain kinds of collective market behaviour would be an appropriate means of achieving countervailing market power.

Is that not what the Wheat Board is all about? It is not the monopoly that it is so often painted; rather, it is the collective of the 45,000 wheat farmers. It is their marketing arm. It is not the monopoly so often painted by the deregulators. The Board's charter is for the farmers. The grain merchants' charter is for fly-by-night shareholders who are usually made up of insurance companies. Surprisingly, though-other than the Government's view, which is no surprise-the extreme economic dries have come out in support of the Government plan. They need to examine the worth of their very narrow ideological path which overlooks economic efficiency on a broader scale.

As is the case with all small business, family farms are the dynamo of private enterprise. Family farms represent Australian ownership of our natural resources. Such private access is rapidly being denied in other sectors of the economy due to the concentration of ownership in fewer and fewer hands. Further, the integration of the family and the farm-that is, the social unit and the economic unit-is of great value to this country. If the ideologues are seeking deregulation that will produce efficiency, there are clearly two ways to achieve it. The first is to accept the recommendations of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport, which encourage deregulation and thus competition in the handling and transport of wheat. The Royal Commission clearly stated that its recommendations to improve efficiency can be implemented within the existing market arrangements of the Wheat Board. Secondly, the proposed arrangements can alleviate the heavy burden of protection of other industries that the wheat industry carries. To illustrate the size of this burden, the Impact Project Research Centre at the University of Melbourne calculated that if this burden was removed real net returns to farms in Australia's wheat growing zones would increase by approximately 18.4 per cent. Why do they not get off the farmers' backs?

It is true to say that the marketing arrangements are very complex and that those outside the industry, particularly from suburban Australia, do not have a grasp of the issue. However, the acid test for those city dwellers is whether the new arrangements will lead to increased bread prices or lower bread prices. The answer is that they will not lead to lower bread prices. Both the producer and the consumer will lose out, leaving the middle men, the grain merchants, as the real winners. That is not very good economics. The New Zealand industry, which was deregulated in 1987, has experienced a savage downturn in grower returns. Growers have taken at least a loss of $NZ100 per tonne. Meanwhile, the bread prices in that country have risen almost every month. The New Zealanders have found that after deregulation the wheat price is set by the weakest seller and the bread price is set by the strongest seller.

The Government's plan will not only affect the domestic market, but it will also be the thin end of the wedge of deregulating the export market. Under the proposed legislation the grain merchants, those like Elders and Bunges, will overbuy on the domestic market and end up with unsold stock. This will have the effect of lowering prices for the grain growers in the following season and the grain merchants will go running to the Government pleading for permission to export their surplus. They will make this plea in the name of helping the current account and supporting the collapsing domestic price. The cries will arise that a deregulated domestic market and the Wheat Board's export powers are incompatible and therefore the export market must be deregulated as well.

In any case, the Wheat Board will find itself snookered by the grain merchants when the Board comes to fulfil its export quotas. Under the legislation the grain merchants can buy such a significant proportion of the wheat that the Australian Wheat Board will have to try to buy back that wheat to fulfil its own export contracts without having control of the receival standards, once enforced by the Board prior to this legislation, in storage and handling. So there will be an inevitable lowering of receival standards in particular in the quality needed by the Wheat Board to fulfil its export market demands and this will affect Australia as a selling nation.

Australia could lose its primary distinguishing feature in a highly competitive market. How does the Parliament think we are able to be competitive in wheat sales against the United States or Canada? Our advantage is quality and price and the grain merchants will now be able to get a foothold in, if not the control of, the quality and price of the export market. I have the firmest conviction that the whole system is headed for a major breakdown under this legislation.

I further wish to relate my remarks to the abolition of the underwriting scheme. Underwriting is the cornerstone of any orderly marketing system. It has been responsible for effectively and efficiently allocating resources in many primary industries. It has allowed many family farmers to live and stay on the land with a certain amount of income security. Underwriting provisions have helped protect against the effects of a collapse of international prices and to ward against corrupt world prices specifically emanating from the United States. It is a very small price to pay for an industry which returns so much to the nation. It is also worthy to note that the existing system of underwriting has been triggered only on one occasion, in the 1986-87 season. Since that first underwriting provision was triggered, the Treasury has set about attempting to have it abolished. The legislation effectively does just that. The scaling down of the scheme over five years to 80 per cent of the expected pool returns means that the level of underwriting is placed at such a distance from market reality that it will not be triggered.

Further to this particular act is the power of the Minister to veto the prices offered to the farmers by the Australian Wheat Board, resulting in an even greater likelihood that the provision of underwriting is simply a facade in the market place. It is then important for the Senate to support the amendments of the coalition to maintain the 95 per cent underwriting provision. It is the last hope of salvaging for the industry some form of orderly marketing.

I wish to address myself to the Government's claims that it is replacing orderly marketing with commercial flexibility. It is hardly giving the Wheat Board commercial flexibility when the prices offered by the Board must be cleared by the Minister. It is hardly giving the Wheat Board commercial flexibility when the Board cannot borrow in the marketplace without the approval of the Minister. It is hardly giving the Wheat Board commercial flexibility when the Minister has control over the expenditure of the proposed growers' levy. It is hardly giving the Wheat Board commercial flexibility when the Government guarantee for the Wheat Board's raising first cash advancement payments is only $100m, when $500m is required to compete with the billion dollar grain merchants.

So much emphasis has been placed on the Government's great micro-economic reform leap forward. It is rubbish and it is being done with mirrors. Irrational deregulation is being forced on the wheat industry whilst, on the other hand, the Government has failed in all areas of micro-economic reform. It has failed in privatising Qantas and Australian Airlines. It has failed to bring real competition to Australia Post and Telecom. There has been no micro-economic reform in the labour market, coastal shipping and the waterfront. Waterfront efficiency is less than half that in other Western nations. The waterfront does not even have to compete at commercial international standards, let alone in a corrupt world market, as the wheat farmers do. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has caved in to the Waterside Workers Federation and promised that any reforms will not adversely affect its monopolistic stranglehold on the industry.

On every front where micro-economic reform would threaten the perks of Labor's constituency of unions and bureaucrats, the Government has cast aside micro-economic reform that would benefit the nation as a whole. In desperation, the Government has turned on the efficient wheat farmers and the Wheat Board to attempt to prove its credentials on deregulation.

Either by sloppiness in drafting the Bill or owing to the Government's full intent, the Bill threatened all primary produce marketing systems. When the Bill first entered Parliament, the Government had included a proposed section 88 which would have ridden roughshod over State primary produce marketing boards. Section 88 took in not only wheat but read, `or any other products of the soil.' This section would have placed at risk the orderly marketing systems of every primary industry in Australia. It would have opened the way for across the board deregulation, regardless of its merits, in each industry of the rural sector. It could have wiped away the orderly marketing systems that rural producers strived for and operated successfully over many decades. While the Opposition has succeeded to some extent in averting this threat, the original clause demonstrated the sloppy manner in which the Government prepared these Bills for Parliament. This appalling preparation in turn reflects the Government's attitude towards the fundamental needs of the agricultural sector.

The Government has had to prepare more than 40 amendments to these Bills in addition to the 40 amendments proposed by the Opposition in the other House. Many amendments relate to the very Bill which I understand was prepared over 12 months ago. This debate has been raging for 12 months and the Government could still not get it right when it tabled the legislation in the other House. It is a mockery and a myth, peddled by who knows, that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is in some way an improvement on all the past Labor Ministers responsible for agriculture. He is not better. He is worse. He is probably worse than any of the Ministers in that treacherous Whitlam Government that hated farmers. I believe that Mr Kerin is not as open but is far more cunning and devious in his manner and in his ways.

It is worthy to mention the amendments being moved by the coalition parties. They are aimed at bringing some sense into the Bill. They are aimed at strengthening the Wheat Board's representation of growers on the Board. While I am opposed to the dismantling of the Wheat Board's existing powers to compulsorily acquire the Australian wheat crop destined for human consumption, the coalition amendments have my support if we are to have a deregulated market. However, I maintain my strong belief that this legislation is fundamentally flawed and I signal my support for the amendments that have now been coined the Fisher amendments.

In the other place the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) moved several amendments that have the purpose of returning to the Wheat Board the compulsory acquisition powers in the domestic market. Those amendments are now to be moved in the Senate and will gain my support.

I realise that the wheat issue is complex and detailed. Many members do not believe it is a real issue in their State or electorate. Indeed, the events of yesterday's leadership challenge certainly changed many people's view. However, I rely upon the Greek philosopher Socrates of the fourth century BC when I say that it is an issue for today's politics. He said:
Nobody is qualified to become a statesman who is entirely ignorant of the problem of wheat.
In this context, it is worth asking how many statesmen are in the Parliament today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989 and six associated Bills. If one were a Martian who had landed in this country for the first time one would think, because of the media comments and the events of Monday night and yesterday, that this legislation was something extraordinary in the life of Australian politics. Of course, that is not the case. If one were a migrant to this great nation one would think, because of those events, that this was actually the first occasion the Parliament had discussed matters concerning wheat. That is not the case. This is the eighth occasion that the Parliament has determined to debate, discuss and amend as thought necessary the wheat marketing legislation; legislation that controls and governs the marketing of wheat.

SPEECH.PARA: As we have seen, it is remarkable legislation, not so much because it has come from one of the best Ministers for primary industry this nation has ever had-I will put that one on the record for Mr Kerin-but because of the events that occurred yesterday in both the Liberal and National parties' rooms. Yet again we have seen this legislation not only divide a disunited coalition of Opposition parties but also divide the parties as well. We saw the extraordinary reports in last week's newspapers that the previous speaker, Senator McGauran, was threatened with grievous bodily harm in the corridors of this building. Luckily for the good senator, some of his burly colleagues were in the vicinity, so that harm never actually came to pass.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was nobody to hold him down, either.

—I do not know who would have been held down. All of this is because of the division that has occurred. We have seen many reports in our media about the division between the coalition partners. But if I am to be fair, and I always intend to be fair when I am speaking in this chamber, or in other places, I also have to recognise that the legislation has caused division within my own Party, too, both within the party room and between our State branches, our State governments and the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an issue of great concern. It is perhaps a greater issue for the Australian Labor Party not only because we are in government but also because we represent more rural seats in the House of Representatives, where government is formed, than any other political party in this Parliament. Too often people forget this-not only people out there in the electorate but also people who sit on the Opposition benches, people who go by the name of the National Party, which used to be the Country Party, who no longer represent the interests of country people. The Australian Labor Party is close to the nerve edge of what the people in country areas are thinking. If honourable senators do not accept what I have just said they should remember, when talking about deregulation-which is essentially what the Wheat Marketing Bill and associated Bills are about-that it was not this Government that commissioned the Bradley Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission, which advocated deregulation. It was not the Government that commissioned the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunication Services in Australia, which examined Telecom and which was criticised not so long ago in this chamber as not going far enough to deregulate vital means of communication for country people. It was not an Australian Labor Party senator who made that criticism in this chamber; it was a coalition senator who is reputed to be Irish, although he talks slightly differently from me. Perhaps his credentials could be checked one day. But I will not go to the extremes that some of my parliamentary colleagues from Western Australia have gone to.

I will put it on the record that I was very pleased to see the photograph in today's Canberra Times of the two battlers actually shaking hands and making up. I think that their having made up is somewhat of a veneer because the divisions are still very much there. There are still differences between the coalition partners, despite the change of leaders and the forthcoming change on the front bench. We on this side of the Parliament look forward with eagerness to those changes to see who will get the nod and who will be knocked back. I am sure that people on the other side of the parliamentary benches will also be looking at those changes with extreme interest.

The wheat marketing issue has been around for some time. As I said in my opening comments, it is not the first time that the Parliament has discussed such legislation. It is the eighth time the wheat marketing plan has been reviewed. I do not think that the events of the last few days have been matched in the past but certainly past events have been controversial. I will not dwell too much on history because we live in a rapidly changing environment, with new technology being introduced on a daily basis. This is impacting not only on the lives of honourable senators-I know a lot of Opposition senators have still not come to grips with it-but also on the community, including people in the country areas. Technology has been increasing apace. Legislation has to try as best it can to accommodate those technological changes.

We instituted a Federal and State royal commission into grain transport, handling and storage, the McColl Royal Commission, which reported to Parliament last year. It made substantial recommendations, not all of which have been accepted by Government. The recommendations that were put forward were purported to benefit the wheat producers. Another report of extreme interest to this debate tonight was one that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC)-or, as some people refer to it, the `Industries Assassination Commission'-put forward to the Government. This report is perhaps a little drier in outlook than that which came from the Royal Commission. I am happy to say that the Government on this occasion did not accept all the recommendations put forward by the IAC.

The recommendations of both the Royal Commission and the Industries Assistance Commission were debated at length in the States. Meetings were organised by the Grains Council of Australia. I know that in my own State of Western Australia those meetings were very well attended because I attended some of them, in company with my parliamentary colleague on the Opposition benches, Senator Panizza. There was deep concern about what the Government might do in regard to the deregulation of grain handling, storage and marketing, particularly as it related to wheat. As I said, the meetings were exceptionally well attended and the resolutions that were carried were generally in opposition to what had been announced as Government plans.

The fact that some of us sit on the government benches does not mean to say that we do not listen to the community. We did listen to the community and we did bring the concerns back to the Minister. I had a number of discussions with the Minister and his staff. I took part in a delegation from the Western Australian State Government led by the then Minister for Agriculture, Mr Julian Grill, who put forward in a very forceful manner the views and concerns of the Western Australian State Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could not have listened to him too much either.

—The Minister actually did listen to him. Although the Western Australian State Government was opposed to many of the proposals advanced by Minister Kerin in this particular piece of legislation, it put its case in a frank and forthright way, rather than doing what the Opposition sought to do. Instead of sitting down and working out arguments and listening to proper debate, those opposite went away and sharpened knives. We were a wee bit different. We were constructive. We wanted to service our electorates, the wheat farmers in the rural seats-and not only the ones whom we represent, but also the ones whom those opposite purport to represent but from whom, unfortunately, they run away.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious from the contributions made in this chamber in very recent times that a number of people, including honourable senators who are members of the National Party, have not actually yet read the Bill, despite the conflict and concerns that they have expressed. I do not want to go as far as to name the good senators whom I accuse of not having read the Bill, the Minister's second reading speech in this place, or even the amendments which were moved in the House of Representatives and which were accepted by the Government. One particular senator alleged that, through clause 88 of the Bill, the Government would control the marketing, storage and handling not only of wheat but also of every other grain material, including lupins and so on.

A good senator, standing up here and opposing the Bill but supporting the amendments, forgot that an amendment to stop the Government having those powers had already been moved in the House of Representatives and had been accepted by the Government. That is an appalling omission by a senator who is supposed to represent the State for which that senator was elected. I am sure that Senator Panizza, because he has grabbed for his newspaper, picked up the same thing that I picked up, namely, that the senator who made that comment did not actually know what the same good senator was talking about.

It goes even further than that. I am sorry to continue the embarrassment to our troubled parliamentary colleagues who sit on the Opposition benches. The contributions made here this afternoon and this evening showed that there were a number of senators who do not understand the powers which will be given or maintained when this Bill passes through this Parliament. We have been criticised on the basis that we are not doing enough to control the marketing of grain within the States. I suppose that, if farmers are of a mind that the Commonwealth Government ought to be doing that and they are making their representations to elected representatives who sit on Opposition benches, they have the right to put that concern forward.

But, there is a distinct obligation on elected representatives, irrespective of which political party they belong to, to understand the constraints imposed upon the Parliament and the Commonwealth Government by the Constitution. Whether or not representations have been made to honourable senators on the Opposition benches, and whether or not concerns have been raised with them, and even if there is a will for us to do it, we cannot do it because the Constitution prohibits us from doing it. Unfortunately, we have to endure a whole series of speakers, many of whom just do not know what they are talking about.

That is particularly unfortunate because of all the happenings of the past couple of days. I have a certain degree of sympathy for people when they get knocked off from the leadership positions because, let us face it, we are all in the same game and we know how tough the game is. When they get knocked off one can feel somewhat sorry for them momentarily, whilst we rub our hands with glee that it has happened. That they have been knocked off by people who do not know what they have been talking about on this very controversial piece of legislation is an indictment not only of the individuals who have made that admission here in the Senate tonight but also of their political parties and their decisions in their party rooms as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not know who voted for whom; so how can you say they are the ones who knocked them off?
—Senator Panizza keeps interjecting. Senator Panizza has a great claim to fame--
—Leave him alone.
—I am actually going to compliment him. He has a great claim to fame back in our home State of Western Australia where he claims to be the only rural senator.
—I am, too.

—Well, I notice that you give two addresses and not just one. You utilise the facilities of the metropolitan area. I am not criticising you. I commend you for taking the action of going to live and work in a country area. I know that you use your electorate office in a country area, and I commend you for that.
—My electorate office is in Perth, but I have never lived anywhere except in Southern Cross.
—Order! There is too much audible conversation. Senator McKiernan, please address your remarks through the Chair.

—I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. Perhaps my comments earlier on were a bit biting and now that I am actually handing out compliments they cannot be taken. I will return to the Bill, which is the important thing before us. In talking about the Bill, I again commend my Opposition parliamentary colleague for his statement here in the chamber tonight that he will not now cross the floor and vote against the Government's legislation. There had been some thoughts that perhaps he might do so. I commend him for his admission that he has a pang of conscience about doing that. That is something that happens to us all, in all political parties. Not all the time do we agree with everything contained within majority decisions of our respective parties. I understand what Senator Panizza is doing, and I understand his conscience. Quite frankly, I do not agree with each and every thing that is contained within this particular piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that it will not have the same impact in terms of the movement of grain throughout the States. It will not have the same impact upon my State as it will have in States like Victoria and Queensland. While there are some concerns on the part of the trade union movement in my State, I am aware that those concerns are of a much more serious nature in States like Victoria and Queensland. I met with some union officials who came to Canberra to put their concerns to us, and I understand their concerns. Those union leaders are doing what they were elected to do, which is fighting for the jobs of their members.

On the one hand, we government members and senators are criticised because, it is alleged, we follow blindly the dictates of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. On the other hand, it is alleged, as has been alleged to me in the chamber tonight, that we are selling out the workers of Australia. That is the conflict we have to live with on this side of the Parliament. It is not quite as difficult as the conflict which people opposite have had to live through during the past few days and months. It is, nonetheless, a conflict that we have to live through.

Many of us are, and will be, making strong representations to Government to protect those jobs in the future. There is a need to ask the Government to examine in depth and in detail the implications to Australia's road system if there is a general shift away from the movement of wheat by rail back to road in a deregulated environment. Whilst rail has to more or less support itself-although it is subsidised-at least State and Commonwealth governments get a return from that system. We get very little return from the roads system-certainly not the same level of return we get from rail. We will be making strong representations to that effect.

I recognise the enormous contribution made by the previous Western Australian Minister for Agriculture to debate on this issue. I also recognise the strong contribution made by the current Minister for Agriculture. Earlier I mentioned clause 88 of the Bill and that an Opposition amendment was accepted in the other place. Strong representations were made on behalf of the Western Australian Government, and on behalf not only of wheat growers but also of grain growers to free up the provisions of this particular clause. Ernie Bridge did the job and did it well. He has a lot to live up to in following in the footsteps of Julian Grill. Looking at what he has done so far, he will certainly give Julian Grill a good march for his money.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for the pats on the back. Now get back to the Bill.

—I will get back to the Bill. One of the disappointing features of the events of the last few days is the reported decision by another Western Australian member of parliament. I had rather looked forward to being joined on aircraft travelling to this place and home again by the now Leader of the National Party in Western Australia, Hendy Cowan. Unfortunately, it would appear that Hendy has now taken the decision that he is no longer quite so interested in being the candidate for the Federal seat of O'Connor in Western Australia. I think it is a great shame because whilst Hendy has made an unfortunate choice in joining the National Party, I think--
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Panizza may laugh but I am aware that there are difficulties between the National Party and the Liberal Party in Western Australia. Perhaps his laughter emphasises those differences. I think even he would have to recognise the contribution that Hendy Cowan has made to Western Australia over quite a period. I am quite disappointed that Hendy will perhaps not be joining us here. I hope he reconsiders his decision. We might even look forward to seeing a reunification similar to that which we saw today when Mr Tuckey and Senator McGauran shook hands. We have witnessed, in the corridors of this place, differences between Mr Tuckey and Senator McGauran which nearly led to their coming to blows. Things get a lot more heated between Mr Cowan and Mr Tuckey in their home State.

SPEECH.PARA: I intended to make some comments about previous speakers. I have already mentioned some of them. I draw the Senate's attention to the contribution made by my colleague Senator Parer. Senator Parer's contribution this evening was another frank admission that the Opposition parties do not know what they are talking about when speaking to the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989 and associated legislation. Senator Parer, rather than referring to the fine details of the Bill-and I hope that we will be able to do so in the committee stage-engaged in what is now traditional for him: union bashing. He jumped on the bandwagon and mentioned a whole number of irrelevancies about what happened during World Expo 88 and so on. He belongs to a political party which advocates deregulation. I think the Bill is controversial and historic. It will go forward with the support of all parties, although some amendments will be moved. I think it is a useful piece of legislation and I certainly hope that the debate in the community continues.
